p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the 28th report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th Parliament, together with 73 petitions and 96ministerial responses to petitions previously presented—you might need a forklift for them!

In the last sitting week I tabled the committee's report on its inquiry into petitioning security and accessibility. During this inquiry, the committee conducted a thorough examination of the security features of the House e-petitions system and considered what impact they had had on the public accessibility of petitioning.

The committee also considered whether additional security features, such as the use of official records to verify identity should be implemented, if an age requirement should be imposed on petitioning and whether the current practice of users self-declaring their Australian citizenship or residency was enough to uphold the legitimacy of the petitioning process.

Throughout the inquiry, the committee were particularly mindful of how any change to the system would impact on a person's democratic right to petition the House, and to ensure that the process for petitioning electronically was, as far as possible, no more onerous than signing or creating a paper petition by hand.

The committee's final report on the inquiry provides a thorough presentation and analysis of the evidence received, including from some international and domestic jurisdictions that support petitioning. In the report, the committee concluded that any proposed changes to the current system security or processes, beyond routine upgrades, would disadvantage certain cohorts of the community and diminish their right to accessible petitioning. The committee therefore made no recommendations for change, but instead will continue to monitor the current process and conduct reviews as necessary.
I look forward to further updating the House on the work of the Petitions Committee.
Chair Mr Ken O'Dowd MP
Deputy Chair Hon Justine Elliot MP
Mrs Bridget Archer MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Ms Gladys Liu MP
Mr Julian Simmonds MP
Mr James Stevens MP
Ms Susan Templeman MP

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and Ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session on 26 May, 2 June, 16 June, 23 June, 15 July, and 4 August 2021
1. The committee resolved to present the following petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

PETITIONS
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:04): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, and in accordance with standing order 207, I present the following petitions:
COVID-19: Vaccination
There is currently a massive human tragedy taking place in parts of the world as a result of the pandemic, most notably India who's medical system has been overwhelmed.
Australia has, through swift action and natural affordance of being a well isolated / sparse population, brought the pandemic under control.

We therefore ask the House to delay vaccinations to the general population. Following the completion of Phase 1b, we ask that Australia re-route it's available vaccine supply to those nations who's medical system has collapsed from epidemic conditions.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN2673)
COVID-19: International Travel
International travel to see family overseas
Australia has thousands of residents and citizens with family over the world
We have the right to visit our family many have elderly parents siblings and extended family.
It is a basic human right to see them.
People have sick family members dying and cannot say goodbye.
Family is very important and time is very precious.
We therefore ask the House to
Allow international travel to see family overseas not just on compassionate grounds for the basic right to see family
from 1,070 citizens (Petition No. EN2677)
Food Imports

plenty of foods from overseas are imported but very few are checked. we need more % and vigorous testings be done regarding pesticides, formaldehyde (in fish), additives and metallic toxins. if we are lax about tit, that will only add to our medical expenses of our health system in Australia. so....PREVENTION IS BETTER THAN CURE!

We therefore ask the House to PASSA RESOLUTION ASKING THE AGRICULTURE DEPRTMENT TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF STAFF, INCREASE THE % OF TESTINGS AND INCREASE THE VIGOUR OF THE TESTINGS, TO AVOID HIGH EXPENDITURE TO THE HEALTH SYSTEM.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN2679)
Youth Allowance

The Centrelink Age of Independence for Youth Allowance sits at 22. Young Australians can drink, smoke and drive at the age of 18 but are not considered independent. Even students moving out of home to attend university can be denied access to income support based on a parent or partner's income. In the higher education sector, the global pandemic has meant that students are more vulnerable and poorer than ever before. Students are the victims of the casual workforce, penalty rate cuts and the shutdown of industries predominantly worked in by young people due to COVID-19. With funding provided by Universities drying up and the Federal Government income support being reconsidered, anyone can see the impending impact on young people.

The health crisis isn't over and the economic crisis certainly isn't over. We should be ensuring that Australia's future is well protected by investing in young people to be able to live and study and not sending them through the cracks of our welfare system to potential lifetimes of poverty. We need to fund our future.

A liveable wage is essential so students are not skipping meals, going without medication, sleeping rough or couch surfing. Recognising that young people are independents from the age of 18 is critical to assist those in difficult or unstable households and queer youth.
We therefore ask the House to lower the Centrelink Age of Independence from 22 to 18.
from 13,360 citizens (Petition No. EN2680)
Immigration

With the government beginning to discuss migration levels once again, we believe it is necessary to make changes whilst we are in a position to do so during the COVID-19 pandemic at a time of zero immigration.
The current level of migration is the merging of a whole lot of vested interests:
- The government loves immigration because it increases the tax base/forward estimates without having to do anything beyond changing a number on a spreadsheet.
- Big business loves immigration because it grows markets and pushes down wages.
- The real estate industry loves immigration because it pushes up housing prices.
- The building industry loves immigration because it creates demand.
- Universities love immigration because it props up their balance sheet.

In the absence of mass migration during the COVID-19 pandemic, we have seen living standards actually increase in 2020 at a faster rate than the average over the past decade, rapidly declining unemployment rate and forecasted acceleration in wage growth.
We believe the government should stand for the Australian people, not big business who are for a big Australia and do not have our interests at heart.
We therefore ask the House to impose more sustainable cap of 70,000-80,000 permanent migrants per year inline with last century averages.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN2681)
Census

The census is an important tool to identify the demographic of Australia population. Currently while Cantonese is recognised as "language spoke at home", this does NOT reflect the unique identity of Cantonese-speaking Hong Kongers. Culturally Hong Konger's identity are not the same as Mainland Chinese or Taiwan Chinese, there are major cultural difference between ethnic Chinese originated from Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia...etc. Grouping all ethnic Chinese together in the census will affect government services for Cantonese-speaking Hong Kongers as well as other. Therefore these culturally diverse group should be separated at the census. This is to ensure the unique identity of Cantonese-speaking Hong Kongers recognized in Australia,
We therefore ask the House to recognise the unique identity of Cantonese-speaking Hong Kongers in all future census from 2021 onward.
from 2,520 citizens (Petition No. EN2682)
COVID-19: Cruise Industry

Cruising is a much loved and missed holiday type in Australia. The cruise ban that is STILL in place after the effective eradication of SARS-CoV-2 in our country is unnecessary. Cruisers are desperate for their cruise holidays.

There are ways to safely get vaccinated crew and ships to Australia, and with careful health and safety measures, domestic cruising can resume with Australians on board. We are already granting entry exemptions for thousands of overseas workers to support industry - crew are no different. The ban is continuing to be economically damaging, losing Australians businesses, jobs and income.

Cruise lines globally have committed to extensive new health protocols in response to COVID-19, including 100% testing of all passengers and crew. With these measures in place, we see an opportunity for a carefully managed and phased resumption of cruising in Australia.

Some will wait, but the vast majority of cruisers would get on a ship from Australia tomorrow if they could. Cruising has resumed very successfully in many other parts of the world, including Europe and Singapore. No other country with cruises resumed have eradicated the virus from their countries, yet they are STILL safely cruising.
There are NO good reasons to continue this ban. It's time to safely allow ships back.
We therefore ask the House to lift the ban on foreign flagged ships and allow cruising to resume in Australia with Australian's on board and include them in future 'travel bubbles'.
from 66 citizens (Petition No. EN2683)
Suicide Prevention
Nine Australians die everyday by suicide, and over 65,000 people make a suicide attempt each year.
When a person is in a crisis state of mind, they need quick and easy access to help.
Yes we have multiple helplines available, but do you know their numbers off the top of your head?
Suicide survivors have explained that moments before an attempt, you are fighting with your own brain. "It does not let you access other ways of thinking".
This is why a 3 digit suicide prevention hotline is needed.
A simple and fast number that everyone can remember, no matter what state of mind.
If we have a simple 3 digit number, kids can also learn this number in school. Friends and family members can also rely on this for instant help for their loved ones.
Every second counts for those contemplating suicide, lets make access for them simple.
Please sign and help show your support, so we can help those that struggle in silence.
We therefore ask the House to put In motion a 3 digit suicide prevention hotline.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN2684)
COVID-19: Skilled Migration Program

Australia's economy has been plummeting since the past year and businesses have closed due to the border closure in place. We need skilled workers back into Australia especially on the hospitality and tourism sector which has been deemed as critical sectors.
We need them now more than ever for the recovery of the country's economy as their purpose of going into Australia is beneficial to the country.

We therefore ask the House to make an appeal to the Federal government and to the Australian Border Force to allow skilled workers and their dependents back into Australia and urge the Federal government to build legitimate quarantine facilities in order to enlarge the cap of inbound travelers without compromising the quarantine slots for Australian coming back home.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN2685)
Freedom of Speech

We are Australian Christians that are concerned with the quality and value the Christian voice currently has in our country. That our basic fundemental freedoms to speak about our faith is being repremanded and vilified not only in the media but also in institutions and workplaces. We have copious examples of people losing jobs just for stating they are Christians and their Christian beliefs. Our words of faith are being treated unfairly and unequally comparitively to other belief systems.

We therefore ask the House to view this petition in Parliament in support of the Anti-Descrimination Amendment (Religious Freedoms/ Equality Bill. We believe that Christian entities should have the ability to keep our Christian morals, values and ethics and overall ethos in respect to our Christian organisations and businesses. To continually be true to the Bibles words and to state them both privately and publicly and in a respectful manner. The words of the Bible have been the core foundation to our belief system that has existed for thousands of years, which is a right of every individual to aggregate their own belief systems and follow it. We therefore request that the rights of Christians to speak words of the Bible and pray for others in both private and public spaces be permitted and not be discriminated against, seen as derogatory or hate speech. Australia represents equal rights and a democratic society; therefore we ask for our equal right to be able to live our faith without prejudice or bigoting.
from 71 citizens (Petition No. EN2686)
Agriculture Industry

Soil is a complex and diverse ecosystem filled with living organisms from a diverse range of species, providing a crucial resource for the Earth's ecosystem and anthropic needs of primary food production. These anthropogenic activities are evident globally, particularly within the agricultural sector. The inherent nature of mass-scale intensive cropping systems has favoured poor soil management relying on synthetic external inputs. These activities have left humanity in a precarious position as the soil is ill-equipped to deal with the changing environment. Climate change is the greatest existential threat presently posed to Australia; increased variance of climatic conditions, particularly rainfall, will compound challenges on the driest continent on Earth. Current agricultural practices are not conducive to a sustainable future, particularly in a time of increasing unpredictability. Regenerative agriculture is a farming process that rejuvenates the health of the soil, increasing resilience to all climate stresses without the need for chemicals and damaging practices

We therefore ask the House to to implement: (1) Nationwide education program targeting primary producers and consumers utilising positive storytelling of successful regenerative enterprises. (2) Mandate distribution of literature at rural stores with every pesticide/herbicide sale. (3) Updated best practice guides focusing on soil health. from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN2687)
Broadband

NBN Co have been unable to provide fibre to all Australians - some Australians within 30km of major CBDs have been allocated Skymuster satellite, an inferior alternative, with high latency reducing the value of the service.

International internet satellite operators have commenced operating in Australia, offering competition to NBN, using low earth orbit to provide low latency and very high speeds. The first example is Starlink.
However, the ACMA's spectrum licensing cost, has meant Starlink has chosen to only purchase a license to operate in regional areas.
So a large number of Australians are considered too rural to receive fibre NBN, but not rural enough for NBN's competitor.
Now that Internet is a basic utility, needed in a post-pandemic world of work from home, it is no longer satisfactory to make basic spectrum a source of profit for the government.

In the same way that citizens expect providers of electricity and road access to be able to license the necessary infrastructure affordably, we now expect spectrum to be priced to allow internet access to all of us - we cannot have one government body defining an area as rural, and another defining an area as metro, when they are defining access to the same service.

We therefore ask the House to direct the ACMA to match the NBN satellite allocation area in defining what is low and remote density (area 74) for Spectrum purposes, so that thousands of urban Australians, neglected by the NBN, can have fast access to the internet.

PETITIONS
Responses
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:04): I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Donations to Political Parties
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter to the former Assistant Minister for Finance, Charities and Electoral Matters, Senator the Hon Zed Seselja, dated 19 October 2020, referring to petition number EN1719. As Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, I am responding to the Committee's request.
I note the petition, which requests a Royal Commission into political donations, with particular regard to what the petitioners describe as 'harmful industries'.

Australians enjoy the freedom to engage in democratic discourse that is consistent with the implied freedom of political communication under the Australian Constitution. Participation in a free democracy includes the right for Australians financially support candidates and parties of their choice through donations.

The Government is committed to ensuring transparency and integrity within the electoral system. In 2018, changes to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Electoral Act) banned foreign donations and extended financial disclosure obligations beyond political parties and candidates, to also capture other political actors that incur significant political expenditure. We have also invested in enhancements to the Transparency Register run by the Australian Electoral Commission.

In recent years, successful reforms to Australia's electoral system have followed work conducted by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM). The Committee is currently reviewing the 2018 changes to the Act and will consider any recommendations from that review after the JSCEM reports on 31 May 2021.
For these reasons, the Government does not support the petition's request. Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, Mr Morton
Child Support Agency
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021, concerning petition number EN2138 to the House of Representatives, relating to the child support scheme.

Family breakdowns are incredibly difficult. Child support is in place to ensure that as far as possible, children affected by a family breakdown remain financially secure no matter the custody arrangements. The purpose of the scheme is to facilitate the assessment and collection of child support between separated parents, to assist them in meeting their legal obligation to financially support their children until they reach 18 years of age.

The scheme and the legislation do not make any distinction based on the gender or background of either a paying parent or a receiving parent. The child support scheme is intended to be fair for both parents, so they can manage their financial responsibilities towards their children.
The petitioners may be interested in the following information.
The current child support formula was introduced in 2008 using extensive research undertaken by the Ministerial Taskforce on Child Support on the costs of caring for children in Australia.

Various figures and thresholds in the child support formula, including the Costs of the Children Table and the self-support amount, are benchmarked or indexed using Male Total Average Weekly Earnings (MTAWE), as reported by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. These figures and thresholds are adjusted each year in line with MTAWE, which helps to ensure the formula keeps pace with changes in earnings and the cost of living.

Adjusted taxable income, rather than net or gross income, is used in the child support formula to calculate both parents' incomes. The effect of taxation is taken into account under the child support formula as the same approach is used for both income and expenditure.

Child support assessments are generally based on parents' adjusted taxable income for the last relevant financial year. This is generally the most up-to-date and accurate income information available to Services Australia, and best reflects the parents' true capacity to support their children. This income comprises taxable income (that is, income before tax but after any allowable deductions) and certain supplementary amounts such as foreign income, reportable fringe benefits, tax-free pensions and benefits, total net investment losses and reportable superannuation contributions. The inclusion of supplementary amounts ensures child support liabilities are calculated according to a parent's capacity to provide support for their child, regardless of how their income is structured.

As explained above, adjusted taxable income includes supplementary amounts such as reportable superannuation contributions. Reportable superannuation contributions include discretionary salary-sacrificed superannuation contributions an employee has made in addition to their compulsory superannuation payments.

Reportable superannuation contributions are treated in the same way as wage and salary income because those contributions could have been received as cash. In most circumstances, choosing to invest additional amounts into superannuation is a way of legitimately reducing a person's taxable income. While these arrangements are legitimate for taxation purposes, they should not diminish a parent's fundamental responsibility to support their child in line with their financial capacity.

Compulsory superannuation payments, such as amounts made under superannuation guarantee law or according to an industrial award or agreement, are generally not considered reportable superannuation contributions and are therefore not part of a parent's child support income.

The effective enforcement of child support obligations is central to the integrity of the child support scheme. Some parents will choose not to make voluntary child support payments, and may be subject to enforcement measures to ensure child support is still collected.

In the first instance, Services Australia encourages parents who are behind in their child support payments to enter into a voluntary payment arrangement, to address their debt in the shortest possible time. A payment arrangement will take into account the parent's individual financial circumstances, and Services Australia can periodically review the arrangement to ensure it still reflects the parent's current financial circumstances. Services Australia has extensive enforcement powers, including the ability to directly garnishee wages, recover funds from bank accounts, tax returns or certain income support payments, and the power to prevent child support defaulters from travelling overseas.
Ultimately, Services Australia also has the ability to take litigation action through a court. This option is always given careful consideration prior to action being undertaken.

Services Australia's compliance approach balances education, support, advice and enforcement activities. Enforcement powers also apply equally to both paying and receiving parents, and can be used to collect carer debts as well as child support debts.

span.span: Review of the child support scheme

p.span: The Joint Select Committee on Australia's Family Law System is conducting a wide-ranging Inquiry to ensure that the system operates as fairly and efficiently as possible. It is also looking at how the family law system interacts with child support.

Announced by the Government in September 2019, this Inquiry has provided an important opportunity for parliamentarians to hear from people who have interacted with the system. The Joint Select Committee will report by November 2021. More information is available at
www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Family_Law_System.
The Government is committed to helping families manage their responsibilities for their children following separation and will continue to monitor the effect of child support legislation.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me. I trust the information provided will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Australia Day
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter of 16 March 2021 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, providing petition EN2336 regarding changing the date of Australia Day. As the Minister responsible for the National Australia Day Council, the Prime Minister has asked me to reply on his behalf and I apologise for the delay in responding.
I respectfully disagree with the sentiment of the petition that we need to change the date of Australia Day.
Australia Day is a day to reflect on our shared history, its highs and its lows, to respect the stories of others and celebrate our nation, its achievements, but most of all its people.
It's a time to reflect on the past 60,000 years of Australian history, our many successes, and our failures, and to be grateful for the free and fair democracy we have created for ourselves today.

On Australia Day we welcome our newest Australians alongside the world's oldest living culture and celebrate our diverse background, and the extraordinary achievements that have made Australia a successful multicultural society.

Of course, 26 January means different things to different people, particularly Indigenous Australians. The fact there is discussion around the date means it is an important date. The reason that 26 January means so much in different ways to different people needs to be harnessed.
We can improve the way we celebrate Australia Day by being more respectful and inclusive.
It's important that we reflect on Australia Day on the impact European settlement had on Indigenous Australians and their way of life.
We must and we should include greater recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people's history, traditions and culture. There are important opportunities to tell truth and learn from it.

For example, in Yirrkala in the Northern Territory, Yolngu and Balanda, Aboriginal and non­Aboriginal came together to celebrate Australia Day 2021 as one community. Over 500 people, coming together to the Buku Larrnggay Mulka centre in a COVID-safe way, for a Welcome to Country, smoking ceremony and Bungul.
In Sydney, Australia Day 2021 started with the WugulOra Morning Ceremony at Barangaroo - WugulOra means 'One Mob' and has been a part of Sydney's Australia Day activities for years.
In Perth, the afternoon of Australia Day 2021 featured the Birak Festival, followed by a light show telling the story of Noongar and Whadjuk people.

We can and we are doing Australia Day better. But there's always more that we can do. As Minister for Indigenous Australians, the Hon Ken Wyatt AM MP, put it: "It is also a journey that for some is difficult, it is raw, and it does hurt in parts - but rather than shy away from this, or dismiss our success, we should come together as one this Australia Day and reach out to better understand the Australian story of others."

And Shadow Minister for Indigenous Australians, the Hon Linda Burney MP, agrees: "What I'm saying to Australians this Australia Day is, we don't need to change the date, we just need to change the way we observe the day. Take just a moment to learn about our past. Australia is home to the oldest surviving civilisation - more than 60,000 years - on Earth. This is and ought to be a source of pride for all Australians."

It is why we need to focus on honouring our national day more respectfully, more inclusively, so Australia Day can be a day about bringing Australians together as one, not dividing us - because we are all part of the Australian story.

The National Australia Day Council has been asking Australians to do just that — to reflect, respect and celebrate and recognise that we are all part of the Story of Australia. This message was borne out of a desire to make Australia Day more inclusive of the histories, stories and contributions of all Australians, but especially First Nations people.

National Australia Day Council Director and Walbanga and Wadi Wadi woman, Mrs Alison Page, encouraged all Australians to explore their history together on Australia Day in her opinion piece published in the West Australian on 26 January 2021.
Thank you again for providing this petition to the Prime Minister.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
Australia Day
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter of 16 March 2021 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, providing petition EN2342 regarding changing the date of Australia Day. As the Minister responsible for the National Australia Day Council, the Prime Minister has asked me to reply on his behalf. I apologise for the delay in responding to your letter.
I respectfully disagree with the sentiment of the petition that we need to change the date of Australia Day.
Australia Day is a day to reflect on our shared history, its highs and its lows, to respect the stories of others and celebrate our nation, its achievements, but most of all its people.
It's a time to reflect on the past 60,000 years of Australian history, our many successes, and our failures, and to be grateful for the free and fair democracy we have created for ourselves today.

On Australia Day we welcome our newest Australians alongside the world's oldest living culture and celebrate our diverse background, and the extraordinary achievements that have made Australia a successful multicultural society.

Of course, 26 January means different things to different people, particularly Indigenous Australians. The fact there is discussion around the date means it is an important date. The reason that 26 January means so much in different ways to different people needs to be harnessed.
We can improve the way we celebrate Australia Day by being more respectful and inclusive.
It's important that we reflect on Australia Day on the impact European settlement had on Indigenous Australians and their way of life.
We must and we should include greater recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people's history, traditions and culture. There are important opportunities to tell truth and learn from it.

For example, in Yirrkala in the Northern Territory, Yolngu and Balanda, Aboriginal and non­Aboriginal came together to celebrate Australia Day 2021 as one community. Over 500 people, coming together to the Buku Larrnggay Mulka centre in a COVID-safe way, for a Welcome to Country, smoking ceremony and Bungul.
In Sydney, Australia Day 2021 started with the WugulOra Morning Ceremony at Barangaroo - WugulOra means 'One Mob' and has been a part of Sydney's Australia Day activities for years.
In Perth, the afternoon of Australia Day 2021 featured the Birak Festival, followed by a light show telling the story of Noongar and Whadjuk people.

We can and we are doing Australia Day better. But there's always more that we can do. As Minister for Indigenous Australians, the Hon Ken Wyatt AM MP, put it: "It is also a journey that for some is difficult, it is raw, and it does hurt in parts - but rather than shy away from this, or dismiss our success, we should come together as one this Australia Day and reach out to better understand the Australian story of others."

And Shadow Minister for Indigenous Australians, the Hon Linda Burney MP, agrees: "What I'm saying to Australians this Australia Day is, we don't need to change the date, we just need to change the way we observe the day. Take just a moment to learn about our past. Australia is home to the oldest surviving civilisation - more than 60,000 years - on Earth. This is and ought to be a source of pride for all Australians."

It is why we need to focus on honouring our national day more respectfully, more inclusively, so Australia Day can be a day about bringing Australians together as one, not dividing us - because we are all part of the Australian story.

The National Australia Day Council has been asking Australians to do just that — to reflect, respect and celebrate and recognise that we are all part of the Story of Australia. This message was borne out of a desire to make Australia Day more inclusive of the histories, stories and contributions of all Australians, but especially First Nations people.

National Australia Day Council Director and Walbanga and Wadi Wadi woman, Mrs Alison Page, encouraged all Australians to explore their history together on Australia Day in her opinion piece published in the West Australian on 26 January 2021.
Thank you again for providing this petition to the Prime Minister.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
Human Rights
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 22 March 2021 to the former Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon Christian Porter MP, concerning the House of Representatives Petition EN2367 calling for the Australian Government to immediately cease breaching international human rights law and local Australian law.

Australia is a party to a number of United Nations treaties that protect human rights which are implemented through a range of laws, policies and programs at the federal and state and territory levels. The Government considers that Australia's laws and policies are consistent with the obligations in these instruments. The Government is committed to eliminating discrimination against women. The federal Sex Discrimination Act 1984 makes it unlawful to discriminate on the basis of sex, marital or relationship status, pregnancy or potential pregnancy, breastfeeding and family responsibilities in certain areas of public life.

The Government believes that the family law system plays an important role in helping to identify families at risk and protect them from harm. The Family Law Act 1975 does not contain any presumptions in relation to gender.

The Australian system of government is based on a separation of powers between the Legislature (the Parliament), the Executive (the Government), and the Judiciary (the Courts). It is an essential feature of the Australian system of government that our courts are independent and free of interference from the executive arm of government.

Australia is well served by its judiciary, and allegations about judicial conduct that warrant consideration of removal of a judge from office are extremely rare. However, where required, complaints about the conduct of a judicial officer that may warrant their removal from office are considered by the Parliament under section 72(ii) of the Constitution. Proved misbehaviour or incapacity is required in order for this to occur. Ordinarily it is the federal courts who are responsible for the handling of complaints, consistent with their independence. The complaints and feedback processes for the Federal Court, the Family Court and the Federal Circuit Court are published on the Court's own website.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely,
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash

subdebateinfo.title: International Pregnancy and Infant Loss Remembrance Day

p.span: International Pregnancy and Infant Loss Remembrance Day
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 22 March 2021 requesting consideration of a petition before the Standing Committee on Petitions for 15 October to be recognised as the annual International Pregnancy and Infant Loss Remembrance Day in Australia.

The Australian Government recognises that the loss of a child is a traumatic event that can have long lasting consequences for women and their families. We are committed to reducing stillbirth rates and are investing in a range of measures to achieve this. Our investment in perinatal services and support to date totals $162.3 million. This includes $21.3 million for stillbirth specific measures, such as funding to support stillbirth education and awareness initiatives particularly for groups at higher risk of stillbirth.

In the 2021-22 Budget, we announced a new investment of $1.8 million over four years to help increase the number of stillbirth autopsies to better understand the reasons underlying these tragic deaths. This investment will support our goal to reduce stillbirths by 20 per cent or more by December 2025 and will implement actions in the National Stillbirth Action and Implementation Plan.

We also announced $13.7 million to prevent preterm birth and $47.4 million for universal perinatal mental health screening to build on the National Perinatal Mental Health Check. This will help all expectant parents to access screening services that support improved mental health outcomes.

Further, we provide funding to Red Nose to deliver online and telephone-based bereavement support for miscarriage, stillbirth or newborn death as part of our $43.9 million investment under the Perinatal Mental Health and Wellbeing Program.

Proclamation of 'days of national observance' by the Governor-General is just one of a number of ways to promote the observation of days of celebration or commemoration. National days of commemoration may be observed without a proclamation or intervention by the Australian Government. Mothers' Day and Red Nose Day are among the many examples of days throughout the year that have gained community acceptance as the dates on which particular events are celebrated or commemorated, without government involvement.
Thank you again for writing to me on this important matter.
from the Prime Minister, Mr Morrison(Petition No. EN2389)
Charitable Organisations
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning petition number EN2415, which requests that the advancement of religion be removed as a recognised charitable purpose, as it applies to registration by the Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission (ACNC), with the effect of removing all charitable tax concessions from religious organisations. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

As noted in the petition, eligibility for registration with the ACNC and eligibility for charitable tax concessions are interlinked. Charities must be registered with the ACNC to apply for charitable tax concessions from the Australian Taxation Office.

To become registered with the ACNC, amongst other criteria, an organisation must be a charity which includes having only charitable purposes. Charitable purpose has a special legal meaning, developed over 400 years by firstly, the United Kingdom, and later Australian, courts and Parliament. The courts have recognised many different charitable purposes, and as society changes new charitable purposes have been recognised. The Charities Act 2013, which defines what is a charity, recognises twelve such purposes.

One of the charitable purposes listed under the Charities Act is the purpose of advancing religion. Religion has been accepted as a charitable purpose since the 1600s and the current Charities Act is based on this substantial body of case law. Comparable international jurisdictions, including the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada and New Zealand also consider religion a charitable purpose that benefits the community, and provide tax concessions to religious bodies.

This means that organisations with the purpose of advancing religion are eligible for registration with the ACNC provided they meet all the eligibility criteria. Likewise, registered religious charities, in the same way as all other charities, may apply to access charitable tax concessions provided they meet all the eligibility criteria. Organisations with the purpose of advancing religion have the same registration requirements as organisations that have one of many other charitable purposes. The test for charitable purpose is not specifically a religious one.

Neither the Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission Act 2012, nor the Charities Act 2013, infringe section 116 of the Constitution, as neither Act establishes any religion, imposes any religious observance, prohibits the free exercise of any religion, or introduces a religious test for qualification to any Commonwealth office.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
JobKeeper Payment: Tourism Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 25 May 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2527 - a request for a further extension to the JobKeeper Payment for travel agents and tour operators. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The JobKeeper Payment was designed as a national scheme, to apply consistently across a broad range of Australian businesses and industry sectors. As such, the scheme was not intended to apply individual criteria for the Payment to any specific sector or group of businesses.

The JobKeeper Payment was always intended to be a temporary program designed to support confidence and get businesses back up and running as soon as possible. It was designed to deliver support quickly and at scale and it achieved its objective of keeping business in business and Australians in jobs. JobKeeper supported nearly half of Australian businesses and one-third of all workers.

On 11 March 2021, in recognition that certain sectors would need additional assistance, the Australian Government announced a further $1.2 billion in targeted support for the tourism and aviation sectors. The package included a mix of half-price airline tickets and direct support to keep planes in the air and aviation workers in jobs. Increasing domestic tourism helps businesses along the supply chain including hotels, cafes and restaurants and tour operators get back to normal trading. Through the Tourism Aviation Network Support (TANS) Program, discount ticket prices are available on more than 45,000 fares per week. Australians are able to access these discount fares to 14 tourism regions particularly hurt by COVID-19 for travel through to the end of September 2021.

The Government also provided an additional $130 million to extend the Consumer Travel Support Program for three months to support travel agents. This brought the total level of targeted assistance to $258 million, to help sustain the travel sector as it supports Australian travellers adjust to COVID-safe travel.

The Government appreciates international travel restrictions, passenger caps and quarantine arrangements continue to impact Australia's aviation and tourism sectors. For this reason, we have been working with the New Zealand Government to facilitate quarantine-free travel between Australia and New Zealand to provide a much needed boost to international airline, airport and tourism operators in Australia. From 19 April 2021 visitors between Australia and New Zealand have been able to travel without having to quarantine at either end of their journey. The Government is optimistic that airlines will commence additional services to meet demand generated by the two-way safe travel zone, with benefits anticipated to flow to travel agents as international travel demand increases.

The importance of this announcement is demonstrated by the fact that the Trans-Tasman is Australia's busiest international aviation market with over seven million passengers on the route in the year ending January 2020 before the effects of COVID-19 hit international aviation.

The Government also announced an expansion and extension to its existing SME Guarantee Scheme as part of its commitment to support up to $40 billion in lending to small and medium enterprises. The SME Recovery Loan Scheme has benefitted from an increased government guarantee, allowing lenders to offer a repayment holiday of up to 24 months, longer loan terms, larger loan sizes and the ability for borrowers to refinance existing debt.
The vaccine roll-out is also underway, supporting domestic borders to remain open and providing greater certainty for people to travel for both business and leisure purposes.
For further information on the COVID-19 tourism support plan visit:
www.austrade.gov.au/Australian/Tourism/Tourism-and-business.
For more information on the Government's COVID-19 support for aviation visit:
www.infrastructure.gov.au/aviation/index.aspx#aviation.
For further information on the Small and Medium Enterprise Recovery Loan Scheme visit:
treasury.gov.au/coronavirus/sme-guarantee-scheme.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Intellectual Property
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 24 May 2021 regarding petition EN2561, which requests changes to copyright law to introduce a 'use/sell it or lose it' clause.

I note the petitioners' concern that lack of legal access to copyrighted works, particularly older works, harms the preservation of art and culture. The petitioners propose that a published work becomes part of the public domain if it ceases to be reasonably accessible to purchase, use and/or stream digitally for a certain amount of time without reasonable justification. The petitioners consider that, in these circumstances, the public should not have to wait 70 or more years for a work to enter the public domain to legally access the work.

Copyright law is essential to incentivising creators, and their industries, to create new and culturally relevant content. At the same time, allowing reasonable access to creative content is critical to enhance culture and learning, and drive new creativity and innovation. In particular, where the copyright owner cannot be identified or contacted (as is often the case with older works), copyright owners, users and society as a whole lose out on the potential benefits that could be gained from using such 'orphaned' material.

The Copyright Act 1968 (Copyright Act) seeks to balance the rights of copyright owners to manage and protect their works with the larger public interest to access these works. It does this by giving creators the exclusive right to exploit their works for monetary gain for a certain period. For works such as literary and artistic works, this is usually for the life of the author plus 70 years. During this period, copyright owners generally have the right to control how and when their content is accessed. However, the Copyright Act also provides for exceptions that permit access to works for certain socially useful purposes, in particular to support the education, disability and cultural (libraries, archives, museums and galleries) sectors.

On 13 August 2020, the Morrison Government announced a package of copyright access reforms, principally to clarify and update the current exceptions. The reforms also propose a new scheme that allows for the use of 'orphan works' (where the copyright owner cannot be identified or contacted) if a reasonably diligent search for the copyright owner has been undertaken, while also providing for reasonable payment to the copyright owner for any ongoing use of the orphan work if the owner later comes forward. The proposed orphan works scheme will open access to a larger collection of cultural, historical and educational works held in Australia's cultural and educational institutions, as well as enabling orphaned copyright material to be used in modem creative endeavours.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Aged Care
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 14 May 2021 concerning petition number EN2564 on financing of aged care in Australia.

The Australian Government is committed to transforming aged care so that it meets the needs of senior Australians and their families, now and in the future. We all need to do more to ensure senior Australians are treated with care, dignity and respect and have access to quality care as they age. The Final Report of the Royal Commission into Aged Care Quality and Safety (Royal Commission), released on 1 March 2021, is an important step in what will be a significant transformation in aged care.

The Government has now responded to the Final Report, with a comprehensive aged care reform package announced in the 2021-22 Budget. The Government will deliver a $17.7 billion package for a once in a generation reform of aged care to deliver respect, care and dignity to our senior Australians. The response includes a five-year implementation plan, underpinned by five pillars:
• home care - supporting senior Australians who choose to remain in their home
• residential aged care services and sustainability - improving and simplifying residential aged care services and access
• residential aged care quality and safety - improving residential aged care quality and safety
• workforce - supporting a growing and better-skilled care workforce
• governance - new legislation and stronger governance.

In responding to the 148 recommendations made by the Royal Commission, the Government accepts or accepts in principle 126 recommendations. In addition, the Government supports an alternative approach to another four recommendations, for example where the Commissioners had different views and models on governance and implementation. Twelve recommendations are subject to further consideration or noted in the Government's response.

The Government did not accept six recommendations relating to consumer contributions and fees, including the introduction of a new aged care levy or higher personal income taxation to pay for aged care services.
For further information about the aged care reforms, and the Government's response to the Royal Commission's Final Report, please visit: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/aged-care-reforms.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Hong Kong
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I refer to correspondence from the former Chair of Standing Committee on Petitions, Mr Llew O'Brien MP, of 14 October 2019 enclosing Petition EN1022 concerning the grant of asylum to Hong Kong nationals. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government, together with other governments around the world, has been very consistent in expressing concerns about the imposition of the National Security Law and is troubled by the law's implications for Hong Kong's judicial independence, and the rights and freedoms enjoyed by the people of Hong Kong.

For this reason, on 9 July 2020, the Government announced new extended visa options for students, temporary graduates and skilled workers from Hong Kong. The Migration Amendment (Hong Kong Passport Holders) Regulations 2020 came into effect on 21 August 2020. The amendments support skilled workers and recent graduates from Hong Kong to remain in Australia or relocate to Australia, subject to the lifting of COVID-19 travel restrictions. These measures, which apply to those who hold an eligible Hong Kong passport, are:
an extension of five years for any temporary skilled or temporary graduate visa that was held on 9 July 2020, these visas will now cease on 8 July 2025; and
current and future applicants for temporary graduate or temporary skilled visas will be granted a visa with a five year visa validity where they meet the requirements for those visas.

Australia is committed to its international obligations set out in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol, and other international human rights conventions to which it is a party. Australia does not return individual's to situations where they face persecution or a real, risk of torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, arbitrary deprivation of life or the application of the death penalty.

Australia's Humanitarian Program is designed primarily to assist people who have left their home country because of persecution or severe human rights abuses, and who have no options for return or for resettlement in another country. The Humanitarian Program operates flexibly to respond to evolving humanitarian situations and global resettlement needs. Hong Kong passport holders who believe they are at risk of persecution can apply for a humanitarian visa through our Refugee and Humanitarian program, which is one of the most generous humanitarian programs in the world.

Individuals who arrive lawfully in Australia seeking asylum, and who are found to engage Australia's non-refoulement (non-return) obligations, may be granted permanent protection, subject to fulfilling relevant visa criteria and the health, character and security requirements that apply to all Australian visas. Further information about Australia's Refugee and Humanitarian Program and relevant statistics are available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/what-we­do/refugee-and-humanitarian-rpogram, and
https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/research­and-statistics/statistics/visa-statistics/live/humanitarian-program.

There are a range of other visas which Hong Kong nationals may apply to visit or migrate to Australia. Information on Australian visas is available on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-finder.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1022 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Temporary Protection Visas

I refer to correspondence of 20 October 2019 from the former Chair of Standing Committee on Petitions, Mr Llew O'Brien MP, enclosing Petition EN1048 concerning granting permanent residency to Hong Kong expats currently residing in Australia.
