Thank you for bringing Petition EN1048 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Transport Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I refer to your email of 24 December 2020 regarding petition EN1311, requesting the Australian Government allow the sale of cheap electric vehicles and ban the sale of internal combustion engine vehicles by 2025.
The Liberal National Government is committed to enabling consumer choice for new vehicle and fuel technologies.

The development of electric, hybrid and fuel-cell vehicles is being driven by the world's largest car manufacturers. The number of consumers who choose to buy these vehicles will rapidly increase as these new technologies reach parity with mature alternatives. Australians currently have access to around 50 electric vehicle models, including hybrids, and this is likely to increase as the technology continues to develop.

In September 2020, the Government announced a $1.9 billion package to invest in new energy technologies that will support jobs, strengthen our economy and reduce emissions. This included a Future Fuels Fund that will enable businesses to start integrating new vehicle technologies into their fleets, and address regional blackspots in public charging and refuelling infrastructure.
It will also provide improved information on electric vehicles and charging infrastructure to better inform Australian consumers.
The Future Fuels Package builds on existing Government support including:
$21 million to roll out ultra-fast charging sites through two networks along Australia's national highways;
Up to $1.1 billion in finance available through the Clean Energy Finance Corporation to assist uptake of low and zero emissions vehicles;
$25 million for the Future Battery Industries Cooperative Research Centre; and
$4 million for hydrogen transport-related demonstration projects.

The Government is developing a Future Fuels Strategy that will support people to adopt new technologies where it makes sense for them to do so, including hybrids, hydrogen fuel cell vehicles and electric vehicles.
We will work together with industry and research institutions to deploy the right technology when and where it is needed to improve consumer choice, reduce bills and lower emissions.
Technology, not taxes, will be the way we deliver practical action on emissions reduction.
Thank you again for your letter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction, Mr Taylor
COVID-19: Small Business
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 August 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1606 which seeks more support for small businesses during the COVID-19 outbreak and a review of Australian competition law. Please accept my sincere apologies for the delay in response. I have received a large number of emails and requests for information and have not been able to respond as quickly as I would like.

The Australian Government recognises that the once-in-a-century shock imposed by COVID-19 warrants an extraordinary level of support across the economy. The Government's Economic Recovery Plan has been designed to support Australian households and businesses through this exceptionally difficult period. It has helped keep businesses in business and Australians in jobs through the JobKeeper Payment and Boosting Cash Flow for Employers, and supported Australians in need with the Coronavirus Supplement and Early Release of Superannuation.

The Government's response is now transitioning to ensure the Australian economy recovers strongly by targeting additional temporary support measures to boost household incomes, bring forward business and infrastructure investment activity, and drive the unemployment rate back down. More information is available at: www.budget.gov.au/2020-21/content/covid-19.htm.

The Government believes effective competition is essential for a strong small business sector, better consumer-outcomes and a strong economy, and it has therefore taken steps to strengthen Australia's competition laws. The first major review of Australia's competition laws and policy in more than 20 years was completed in 2015. This review's finding resulted in major legislative reforms which took effect in November 2017. These reforms strengthened the prohibition on the misuse of market power, prohibited anti-competitive concerted practices, reformed merger approval processes and made a wide range of other improvements to competition law.
I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Environment
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 19 October 2020 to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Marise Payne, concerning the petition EN1644. Your letter has been referred to me as the Minister for the Environment, as the matters raised fall within my portfolio responsibilities. I am advised there was a delay in your correspondence being received by my department.

The Australian Government is committed to high environmental standards. Our central environmental law, the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act), establishes a rigorous and transparent regulatory framework for protecting nationally important environmental matters, such as threatened species and World Heritage properties, while supporting economic and social outcomes.

An independent review of the EPBC was recently conducted by Professor Graeme Samuel AC, and completed in October 2020. I released the Final Report on 28 January 2021, it is available at epbcactreview.environment.gov.au.

The Government is committed to a staged program of reforms informed by the EPBC Act Review. This includes the delivery of new national environmental standards, which will add clarity about the environmental outcomes that these processes need to deliver.

On 16 June 2021, I released 'A pathway for reforming national environmental law' and an accompanying timeline, that together, outline the Australian Government's staged approach to consider the recommendations of the EPBC Act Review and reform of Australia's national environmental law. These documents will guide the Government as it engages with stakeholders to deliver meaningful and enduring reform in response to the EPBC Act Review. These are available at environment.gov.au/epbc/about/environmental-law-reform.
Thank you again for the opportunity to respond to the issues raised in the petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, Ms Ley
Australian Republic
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 19 October 2020 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, regarding a petition with a reference number EN1729, to make Australia a republic. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf and I sincerely apologise for the delay in responding.

The Prime Minister has expressed his support for current constitutional arrangements. As you may be aware, any proposal to amend the Australian Constitution needs widespread community support to succeed. I add that under the current constitutional arrangements, Australia is a sovereign, independent and federal nation.
The Australian Government respects the right of all Australians to continue to express their views on this matter. The views of the petition have been noted.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
JobSeeker Payment
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email dated 19 October 2020 to the Minister for Government Services, the Hon Stuart Robert MP, concerning petition number EN1766. As the matters raised fall within my portfolio responsibilities, your email has been forwarded to me for reply.

As you are aware, the Australian social security system is a taxpayer-funded, non-contributory system based on the concepts of residence and need. The system targets payments to those most in need through the income and assets tests. In this way, successive governments have ensured there are sufficient resources for those with the greatest need. In making spending decisions, the Government has to balance the need to support Australians with the need to maintain the sustainability of the social security system over the long term.

Working age allowances are designed to provide a safety net for people who require financial assistance, while maintaining incentives for people to join the workforce. Depending on their circumstances, recipients may also be eligible for supplementary payments, such as Commonwealth Rent Assistance .
The Government is acting decisively in the national interest to support households and businesses and address the significant economic consequences of coronavirus.

The Government has extended the temporary Coronavirus Supplement until 31 March 2021. The initial rate of the Coronavirus Supplement was set at $550 a fortnight until 24 September 2020. From 25 September 2020 to 31 December 2020, the supplement has been extended and adjusted to $250 a fortnight. From 1 January 2021 to 31 March 2021, the supplement will be $150 a fortnight to reflect the gradually improving economic and labour market conditions .

In addition to the extension of the Coronavirus Supplement, a number of temporary measures have also been extended until 31 March 2021. These measures include changes to the personal income test for JobSeeker Payment, and changes to the partner income test for JobSeeker Payment.

On 25 September 2020, the personal income test for JobSeeker Payment was temporarily changed to a $300 a fortnight income free area, with a 60 cent taper rate for income above the free area. This is an increase to the previous income free areas for JobSeeker Payment. Currently, a single recipient can earn up to $1,257.50 a fortnight before losing access to their payment. This is an increase from the $1,088 a fortnight recipients could earn under the previous arrangements.

In addition, the temporarily reduced taper rate for the JobSeeker Payment partner income test has been extended until 31 March 2021. Since 25 September 2020, the taper rate has been 27 cents for every dollar of partner income earned over $1,165 a fortnight. This ensures that eligible people with personal income of less than $300 a fortnight can receive JobSeeker Payment and the Coronavirus Supplement provided their partner earns less than $3,086.11 a fortnight.
The combination of these measures ensures that extra support is available to Australians who need it most to deal with the economic impacts of COVID-19.
The Government is closely monitoring the health, economic and social impacts of COVID-19 and will continue to take a measured approach as the situation evolves.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Judicial Appointments
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 19 October 2020 regarding Petition EN1782 on the creation of a more transparent and accountable judicial appointments process. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.

Appointments of judges to Australia's federal courts are important decisions to which the Australian Government gives careful consideration. Consistent with long standing conventions, each government determines its own process for judicial appointments.

As the First Law Officer of the Commonwealth, I am responsible for making recommendations to the Government, and ultimately to the Governor-General, about candidates who are suitable for appointment. Before making a recommendation, I have regard to a broad range of factors, including the expertise and background of potential candidates, and consultation with relevant persons. This ensures all judicial appointments are based on merit.

With respect to the petitioners' calls for comprehensive security vetting checks for current and future judicial appointments, I note under item C.3.1 to policy 9 of the Australian Government's Protective Security Policy Framework, judges of federal courts are exempt from requiring to hold security clearances for the purpose of accessing security classified information while exercising the duties of their judicial office. This is consistent with recommendation 6-2 of the Australian Law Reform Commission's (ALRC) 2004 report, Keeping Secrets: The Protection of Classified and Security Sensitive Information (Report No. 98), which concluded there should be no requirement imposed by the executive government for any judge or magistrate be subject to a security clearance before participating in any case.

As the ALRC observed, '[t]he idea that the executive government could vet judges or magistrates and select who would sit on a court or in a particular case based on a secret security assessment of some sort closed to public scrutiny strikes at the heart of the notion of the separation of powers - which is central to the Australian Constitution - and at the independence of the judiciary and magistracy.'

Further, regarding the petitioners' calls for reform to the process for appointing judges' associates, I note this is not a process managed by the Government. It is an essential feature of the Australian system of government that our courts are independent and free of interference from the executive arm of government. Consistent with this independence , the federal courts are each absolutely and ultimately responsible for managing all employment matters, including the recruitment of non-statutory appointees such as judges' associates.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence, concerning Petition EN1789 - zero deposit property loans for farms, which had five signatures.

There is no legislation requiring banks to seek deposits from prospective borrowers. This is a commercial decision for the lender. A bank will generally require a borrower to provide some level of deposit to reduce its risk in making the loan and meet regulatory requirements to manage its overall risk. The provision of an asset as collateral for a loan may also serve a similar purpose, depending on the nature and value of the loan.

Banks have strengthened their lending standards in recent years in response to specific measures taken by regulators to improve lending practices and limit systemic risks. This has coincided with a moderation in lending, particularly to investors and for interest-only loans. However, recent regulatory actions concerning lending policies were designed with the intent to limit risks to the financial system and broader economy, not to unfairly restrict the ability of particular groups of consumers to access credit.

The Government is aware of recent anecdotal reports that, given the current level of public scrutiny of their past lending practices, banks have become overly cautious in how they are interpreting the application of existing legal and prudential obligations on their lending. In response, the Treasurer has stated publicly that while banks must adhere to regulatory standards, consideration should also be given to the need to provide access to finance for families and businesses, thus facilitating a critical part of the economy.

The Government considers it important that those consumers and businesses with good credit profiles are able to access the finance they need. Ultimately competition, rather than regulation, is the most effective means of creating customer choice.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and the Digital Economy, Senator Hume
Koalas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 09 November 2020 concerning Standing Committee on Petitions, Petition Ministerial Referral (EN1862) upgrade the status of the koala to critically endangered. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The koala (combined populations of Queensland, New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory) is listed as a vulnerable species under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). The Threatened Species Scientific Committee is undertaking a re-assessment the status of the listed koala under the EPBC Act, due to be completed by 30 October 2021.

The Committee's draft assessment is currently open for public comment to 30 July 2021 and is available at environment.gov.au/biodiversity/threatened/nominations/comment. The Committee's draft assessment recommends that the currently listed koala be eligible for listing as Endangered under the EPBC Act.

The Australian Government is leading the development of a national recovery plan for the listed koala and is collaborating with State and Territory Governments to ensure that the recovery plan aligns with their koala plans and strategies and responds to the 2019/20 bushfire impacts on koalas. This will ensure a national and coordinated approach to the long-term recovery of the species.

The draft koala recovery plan is currently open for public comment to 24 September 2021 and is available at haveyoursay.awe.gov.au/koala-recovery-plan. The draft plan proposes six key strategies including increasing habitat protection and strategic habitat restoration.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, Ms Ley
Kurri Kurri: Gas Plant
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 regarding Petition EN2046, requesting the House of Representatives repeal the idea of a gas plant in Kurri Kurri, New South Wales.

On 19 May 2021, I announced that the Liberal National Government had committed up to $600 million in equity for Snowy Hydro Limited to build a 660 megawatt gas power station at Kurri Kurri in New South Wales. This project will help ensure adequate replacement generation is available once the Liddell power station retires, delivering reliable and affordable electricity for households, businesses and industries in New South Wales.
This project will create up to 600 new local jobs during peak construction and 1,200 indirect jobs across New South Wales, delivering an important economic boost to the region.

As more renewables enter our energy system, the Government is working to deliver an affordable and reliable grid. The key challenge to supporting continued strong growth in renewable capacity is to provide backup for when the sun isn't shining and the wind isn't blowing. Gas, including the Hunter Power Project, will support the strong investment in renewables by firming up intermittent renewable energy sources such as wind and solar. The Hunter Power Project will also be hydrogen-ready, enabling it to use clean hydrogen in the future as that fuel becomes cost-competitive.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction, Mr Taylor
Taxation
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2156 -Removal of specific duty free limitations on tobacco and alcohol. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.
The Australian Government has no plans to remove the specific duty free arrangements that apply to alcohol and tobacco carried by incoming travellers on arrival into Australia.

The petitioners specifically highlighted the duty on tobacco as an example. The Government discourages the use of all tobacco products as there is no form of tobacco use which has benign health effects for consumers. Despite the recent decline in the incidence of smoking, it remains a leading cause of preventable death and disability in Australia, with smoking estimated to have killed almost 21,000 Australians in 2015.

The World Health Organisation identifies price increases through taxation as one of the most effective ways governments can reduce tobacco consumption. Successive Australian governments have made significant efforts in recent years to reduce tobacco consumption through staged increases in tobacco excise and a swap to wage indexation.

The taxation of tobacco products, apart from discouraging smoking, helps to pay for support for people who wish to quit smoking, essential services such as the delivery of health services and other areas of spending that benefit the whole Australian community.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Cybersecurity
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, enclosing Petition EN2187 concerning urgent reforms on cyber security reviews. The Minister for Defence has referred the petition to me for response .

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring the secure delivery of Government business. Australia's Cyber Security Strategy 2020 includes the largest ever investment in cyber security by an Australian Government. The $1.67 billion investment will enhance cyber security capabilities, protect essential services, and assist businesses and the broader community. Work is already underway to strengthen the defences of Commonwealth public sector networks.

In December 2020, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit tabled Report 485 on Cyber Resilience. Recommendation 4, which proposes that the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) consider conducting an annual limited assurance review into cyber resilience of Commonwealth entities, is a matter for the ANAO. Responses to the recommendations are due to the Committee by 8 June 2021.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2187 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Compulsory Voting
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 15 February 2021 referring petition number EN2211, which relates to the enforcement of compulsory voting. I am responding as the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters.

Australian citizenship bestows rights and responsibilities to its holders, and one of these is the obligation to participate in federal and state elections. Support of democratic beliefs is fundamental to the Australian identity - which is why all applicants for Australian citizenship must make the following pledge:

span.span: I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
ts and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey.

p.span: Australian citizens, whether by birth or conferral are expected to affirm and uphold these values. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 provides for 'compulsory voting' by requiring all eligible Australian citizens to enrol and vote at each election.

Compulsory voting strengthens our democratic process and ensures that the vast majority of citizens can actively participate in elections. The Government has no plans to remove compulsory voting from Australia's electoral system.
Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, Mr Morton
Australian Public Service
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 16 February 2021 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, enclosing petition EN2221, which requests the Australian Government cut the Australian Public Service (APS) numbers and wages over $150,000 and move departments to other parts of the country. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf. I sincerely apologise for the delay in responding to you.
Everyone in the Australian Government, from the Prime Minister down, appreciates the outstanding work the APS does, particularly as part of the response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

On 9 April 2020, the Government introduced a six-month pause on wage increases for all APS employees. The Government believes that at that time a temporary deferral of pay increases was suitable as it was inappropriate for APS employees who have jobs to be receiving wage increases while thousands of Australians face significant financial difficulty and unprecedented job losses.

The APS is a foundational institution of Australia's democracy. It performs a critical role within the executive arm of Government. Its proper functioning is essential to the future prosperity and security of all Australians and successive governments require the APS to perform efficiently and effectively in order to fulfil their responsibilities.

Regarding the views expressed in the petition relating to removing duplication of functions between the Commonwealth and the States, the Australian federation has a three tier system of government consisting of the Commonwealth, States and Territories and local government. The Australian Constitution specifies the powers and responsibilities of the Commonwealth Parliament and Government. These powers and responsibilities are usually matters of national interest and include trade and commerce with other countries, taxation, postal services and defence. Powers and responsibilities not specified in the Constitution reside with the States and Territories. These include education, transport, law enforcement and health services.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
COVID-19: Australians Overseas
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 19 March 2021 regarding Petition No. EN2298 on support for Australians overseas affected by international passenger arrivals caps.

Supporting the return of vulnerable Australians from overseas remains one of the Government's highest priorities. The Australian Government is focussing resources where the need is greatest, based on registrations of Australians in vulnerable situations.

The Government is providing financial assistance to vulnerable Australians through the Overseas Financial Assistance program. This support aims to help cover living costs and flights to Australia and is available in the form of loans and grants. The loans are only available as a last resort and are subject to strict eligibility criteria. Further information is available on the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) Smartraveller website.

DFAT continues to offer consular assistance to Australians all over the world who have been impacted by COVID-19. The services DFAT can provide are outlined in the Consular Services Charter and include providing Australians with details of local doctors and hospitals.
Australia's COVID-19 vaccinations will be rolled out domestically to people within Australia. Australians overseas should consult their local health professional for advice on vaccine options.

I appreciate it is difficult to return to Australia and acknowledge that the temporary caps on international passenger arrivals into Australia have been extremely frustrating and upsetting for many Australians seeking to return. The decision to introduce the temporary caps on international passenger arrivals was taken by the National Cabinet to safeguard the Australian community and to ensure there is sufficient quarantine capacity to meet the needs of inbound travellers. Airlines determine how they manage the temporary caps in place and decisions regarding seat allocations for commercial flights rests entirely with airlines and may be driven by business considerations.

State and Territory governments, with support from the Australian Government including the Department of Health, manage quarantine arrangements. The Government will continue to work with the Northern Territory to operate government facilitated commercial flights using the Howards Springs quarantine facility. The Australian Government will continue to engage with States and Territories flexibly on additional capacity above the caps to assist vulnerable Australians to return.

As at 23 June, over 607,000 Australians have returned to Australia since the Government recommended people reconsider the need to travel abroad. Since the start of the pandemic, DFAT has helped over 48,700 Australians to return, including around 21,000 people on 142 government facilitated flights from destinations including London, Frankfurt, Paris, New Delhi, Chennai, Johannesburg, Santiago, Los Angeles, Vancouver and a number of ports with direct connections through Singapore. This includes 49 facilitated flights from India and 20 flights from the United Kingdom. On 5 March 2021, the Prime Minister announced the Australian Government would continue to support repatriation flights for Australians through to the end of 2021, as required.
I hope this reassures petitioners of the Government's commitment to assisting Australians overseas.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Overseas Students

span.span: Thank you for your correspondence of 16 March 2021 enclosing Petition EN2338 concerning Singaporean international students and travel restrictions. Your correspondence was referred to me on 30 March 2021 as the Minister for Home Affairs, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

p.span: International students are an important part of the Australian community, and we look forward to welcoming them back to our classrooms, campuses and communities when conditions allow. Protecting the health of Australians and bringing Australians home, especially vulnerable Australians, remains the Australian Government's priority. Across government, careful consideration is being given to how and when this can occur in a COVID-safe way.

The Government is working closely with the states and territories, in partnership with education institutions, on arrival pilots for international students to come to Australia in a managed setting. This will occur following the return of Australians and when other circumstances allow.
Any student arrival plan will need to have robust health, quarantine, border and provider protocols in place to ensure a COVID-safe environment for both Australians and international students.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2338 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: Quarantine
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 3 May 2021 to the Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Karen Andrews MP concerning petition EN2407 calling for the ban on international travel to be revoked. As my portfolio is responsible for Australia's COVID-19 health response, your letter has be referred to me.

On 18 March 2020, the Governor-General declared that a human biosecurity emergency exists under section 475 of the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Biosecurity Act) in relation to the listed human disease 'human coronavirus with pandemic potential' (COVID-19). The existence of a human biosecurity emergency period allows me, as the Health Minister, to determine requirements and give directions under the Act that are necessary to prevent or control the entry, emergence, establishment or spread of COVID-19 in Australian territory or part of Australian territory. The Biosecurity (Human Biosecurity Emergency) (Human Coronavirus with Pandemic Potential) (Overseas Travel Ban Emergency Requirements) Determination 2020 (Overseas Travel Ban) is one of four emergency Determinations currently in place.
The Act requires my satisfaction that the emergency requirements are:
likely to be effective in, or contribute to, achieving its purpose
appropriate and adapted to the purpose
no more restrictive or intrusive than required in the circumstances
are applied in a manner that is no more restrictive or intrusive than required in the circumstances
in place for only as long as necessary.

The Overseas Travel Ban moderates the volume of Australians travelling overseas and thus seeking to return home, reducing the risk posed to Australia's quarantine capacity, health systems, and the Australian community, as well as the risks to those individuals who may otherwise be in a country with high COVID-19 prevalence. The Overseas Travel Ban greatly assists the Australian Government's efforts to prevent and control the entry and spread of COVID-19 in Australian territory.

The Government recognises citizens and permanent residents may have exceptional circumstances or compelling reasons for needing to leave Australian territory. The exemption process overseen by the Department of Home Affairs ensures that the travel restriction is no more restrictive or intrusive than required in the circumstances of the current global pandemic.

The Government and the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee review the emergency period and its response measures, including the Overseas Travel Ban, to ensure ongoing appropriateness and proportionality in terms of global and local epidemiology, including the emergence of more highly transmissible variants.
Opening Australia's borders too soon could see a resurgence in cases, undoing progress and placing strain on Australia's healthcare resources and quarantine systems.

The Government continues to consider when and how to reopen our borders safely. This is a step-by-step process underpinned by the latest medical advice and based on robust risk assessments. Positively, eligible travellers to New Zealand are exempt from the Overseas Travel Ban, under the quarantine free safe travel arrangements between the Australian and New Zealand Governments.

Although Australia has approved COVID-19 vaccines to prevent development of serious disease if an individual becomes infected, the vaccination program should not be viewed as a panacea or a complete substitute for other public health interventions. All Australians must continue with COVID safe practices.

There remains insufficient data as to whether the vaccines also prevent vaccinated individuals transmitting the virus to others. A person could be vaccinated but still be able to transmit. Until there is a better understanding of this, the purpose for rolling out vaccination in the short term is to protect individuals from developing disease. It should be assumed, until proven otherwise, that vaccinated individuals remain potentially infectious to others.
Thank you for bringing this petition and its concerns to my attention
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 13 May 2021 concerning petition number EN2409.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation. It is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

While research into the long-term effects of COVID-19 vaccines is ongoing, the technologies have been studied for years and used in other treatments without issue. Scientists began creating viral vectors like the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine in the 1970s, and mRNA vaccines like Pfizer have been studied before for influenza, rabies and for cancer treatments.

Previous research and vaccine rollout demonstrates that severe side effects are extremely rare and, if they if do occur, they usually happen within the first two months. Because of this, scientists and public-health officials continually monitor vaccine data before, during and after a vaccine becomes available to the public. Both the Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines have been tested in clinical trials since mid-2020 and ongoing trials continue to gather new data over time. Trial data has shown excellent safety results. The first few months of safety data is required before approving any new vaccines. This, plus information coming from vaccine recipients across the world, provides confidence that COVID-19 vaccines are safe.

All vaccines are thoroughly tested to ensure they are effective before approval by the regulator, the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), for use in Australia. Through the TGA, Australia also has a robust system for the ongoing monitoring of vaccine safety. The TGA facilitates a responsive and effective review system to detect any unexpected side-effects from COVID-19 vaccines, if they occur, and ensure they are investigated promptly. This type of monitoring is standard practice in Australia for all vaccines, and draws on Australia's medical expert active and vaccine safety system data gathered through AusVaxSafety.

The long-term effects of COVID-19 infection are, however, well-documented. Although most people with COVID-19 get better within weeks of illness, some people experience post-COVID conditions. According to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, common lasting symptoms of COVID-19 infection are fatigue, shortness of breath, cough, joint pain and chest pain. Other issues include cognitive problems, difficulty concentrating, depression, muscle pain, headache, rapid heartbeat and intermittent fever.

COVID-19 vaccination has not been made mandatory in Australia by the Government and individuals maintain the option to choose. However, it is important that anyone who can receive a vaccination does so, to help keep themselves and others safe. All individuals must give informed consent before having the COVID-19 vaccine, and anyone with questions about the benefits of being vaccinated is encouraged to talk to their doctor or health professional.
Some states and territories have now issued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people working in certain high-risk workplaces only:
Queensland: From 31 March 2021, COVID-19 vaccination is mandatory for all relevant health service employees, Queensland Ambulance Service employees and contractors.
Western Australia: From 10 May 2021, COVID-19 vaccination is mandatory to work in Western Australia's hotel quarantine system.

It is also possible that in the future, vaccination against COVID-19 might become a requirement for travel to certain destinations, or for people working in certain high-risk workplaces. Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there will be exemptions for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons.

Australians are encouraged to rely on reputable sources of information to help them make informed choices and stay up-to-date. To this end, my Department has been communicating regularly about the progress, safety and effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines, with more information available online at: www.health.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Remaining Relative Visa
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021 enclosing Petition EN2414 concerning the eligibility requirements of a Remaining Relative (subclass 115) visa application.

Family migration is an important element of Australia's migration system, allowing Australian citizens and permanent residents to reunite with their family members and contributing to stronger social cohesion outcomes.

Each year, a consultation process is undertaken by the Department of Home Affairs to hear the community's views and inform the Australian Government on both the size and composition of the annual Migration Program.

Following public consultations, the permanent Migration Program is set with Australia's immediate and longer-term economic and social needs in mind. Australia's permanent Migration Program has had a distribution of two-thirds Skill and one-third Family visas since 2005-06.
In 2020-21 and 2021-22, in response to the impacts of COVID-19, the proportion of the Family stream increased to approximately half of the total Migration Program.

The priority in the Family stream category is given to immediate family members who are partner and dependent child applicants. This aligns with the current Government's policy intentions, the need to give priority to certain applications , and to manage the size and composition of the Migration Program.

Visa places are also available, but to a lesser extent, to parents and other family members. The remaining Relative visa is for applicants who have no 'near relatives' other than their visa sponsor. A 'near relative' includes brothers, sisters, parents (or step-equivalents) and non-dependent adult children.
To be eligible for the visa, the person, or their partner, must not have a near relative who lives outside Australia. At present, there is no intention to change these policy settings.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2414 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Social Media
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 12 May 2021, concerning Petition EN2419, calling for new laws to prevent digitals platforms from deleting political content that does not go against their conditions of service.

The Australian Government is committed to promoting the rule of law and the rights and protections we enjoy as a democratic nation. Of these, our right to free speech and free expression is one of the most highly valued and fiercely protected. The ability of citizens to speak freely and openly is the hallmark of a robust democracy.

However, there has never been an absolute right to free speech in Australia. Free speech is balanced against other considerations, such as whether speech is threatening, offensive or defamatory. The Government's position is that measures to filter, block or 'take down' content on social media websites should be used to protect users from harm, such as by removing online abuse material; or to remove material relating to serious criminal activity, such as content that represents an incitement to violence, or is child exploitation or child sexual abuse material.

Major digital platforms sites, including Facebook, Twitter and YouTube, have terms of use that govern how users and others interact with them. Social media platforms are private corporations and are well within their rights to enforce their own terms of use and policies, which users agree to by using their service. It is a decision for the company to determine whether an account or piece of content is in breach of a company's policies and how it will respond. However, the Australian Government expects social media platforms to consistently enforce their standards, so that content that is neither harmful nor in breach of a platform's terms of use is not taken down without reason.

Social media platforms have complaints mechanisms for users to raise concerns about the removal of content and accounts. If members of the public feel that a social media website provider has inappropriately removed their content or breached its own terms of use, they can appeal directly to the provider to seek a resolution.

The petition raises particular concerns with censorship of political discussion, particularly in relation to the United States of America's (US) 2020 presidential election. Social media website providers have made statements that they have flagged or censored user-generated content when that content breaches the website's terms of use, including by spreading misinformation.

The Australian Government supports actions by social media website providers to combat misinformation. Following the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's Digital Platforms Inquiry in 2019, the Government directed industry to develop and implement an industry code of conduct to address disinformation and misinformation on their services. The Digital Industry Group Inc. (DIGI) developed the voluntary Australian Code of Practice on Disinformation and Misinformation (Code) on behalf of the Australian digital industry and released the Code on 22 February 2021. The Code has been adopted by Twitter, Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Redbubble and TikTok, with other digital platforms also encouraged to sign up. Further information on the Code is available on the DIGI website, digi.org.au/disinformation-code/.
Thank you for bringing these concerns to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Working Holiday Maker Program
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021 enclosing Petition EN2434 concerning extending Working Holiday visas granted before the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Australian Government recognises that Working Holiday Makers (WHMs) provide an important cultural and economic contribution to Australia, including through their spending, the work they undertake and job creation in associated industries and businesses. The Government also recognises the importance of WHMs to Australia's economic recovery during and after the COVID-19 pandemic.

The main purpose of the WHM program is to build people to people and cultural links between Australia and partner countries. The WHM visa program is a reciprocal arrangement, agreed between partner countries and is targeted specifically at young people. Australia and most WHM arrangement partner countries have agreed to the 18-30 year age bracket, with the age limit being extended to 35 years on a reciprocal basis with a small number of partner countries. All parameters of the program, including the age limit, are negotiated between countries and set through mutual agreement. These agreed positions cannot be changed unilaterally.

In recognition of the valuable role of WHM visa holders, the Government has introduced a number of measures over recent months. For example, WHM visa holders who were unable to travel to Australia or had to leave Australia early due to COVID-19 will be able to apply for a further WHM visa with no visa application charge (VAC), if they continue to meet the age limit, otherwise they can get a VAC refund if they exceed the age limit.

The reopening of the border to groups of visa holders must be based on expert health advice and balanced against the Government's intent for imposing the travel ban and the health risks posed to the Australian community by international travellers. Further information is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: http://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2434 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
COVID-19: Pacific Islands
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter regarding Petition Number EN2436 which calls for the House to consider supplying COVID-19 vaccines and logistic support to all Pacific Island countries to ensure full population coverage, and permit quarantine free travel within the Pacific region.

The Government has committed to supporting comprehensive vaccine coverage in the Pacific, in coordination with New Zealand, France and the United States. The Regional Vaccine Access and Health Security Initiative includes $200 million to deliver COVID-19 vaccines to the Pacific.

By 12 June, Australia will have provided over 280,000 AstraZeneca doses to Fiji, Papua New Guinea and Timor-Leste, with further deliveries scheduled including to other Pacific countries. On 5 May the government announced a partnership with UNICEF to procure vaccines for up to 6 million people in the Pacific. This is in addition to the $130 million we have committed to the COVAX Facility's Advance Market Commitment, which to date has delivered over 340,000 doses to the Pacific. We are also supporting Pacific governments to roll out COVID-19 vaccines, including through logistical support and training of health workers.
Supporting our neighbours to access vaccines means the Pacific region will be a step closer to international travel when conditions allow, including for Pacific workers.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 13 May 2021 concerning petition number EN2444.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation. It is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

COVID-19 vaccination has not been made mandatory in Australia by the Government, and individuals maintain the option to choose. At the same time, it is important that anyone who can receive a vaccine does so, to help keep themselves and others safe. All individuals must give informed consent before having the COVID-19 vaccine, and anyone with questions about the benefits of being vaccinated is encouraged to talk to their doctor or health professional.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 13 May 2021 concerning the Petition EN2445 on the safety and efficacy of mRNA COVID-19 vaccines.
The Australian Government is committed to providing all Australians with access to safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines to those who wish to be vaccinated.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) undertook an independent and rigorous assessment of the available data for the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine. The data provided to the TGA was comprehensive and included clinical studies, non-clinical and toxicology studies, chemistry, manufacturing, risk management and other information. All data was carefully reviewed by a large team of TGA's technical and clinical experts before provisionally approving the Pfizer vaccine. Supply of Moderna's vaccine in Australia will only commence after the TGA has decided that the potential benefits outweigh the risks for the intended use of this vaccine. An application by Moderna for provisional registration of its COVID-19 vaccine is expected shortly by the TGA.

The Pfizer and Moderna mRNA COVID-19 vaccines have been approved by a number of global regulatory agencies (84 and 46 countries respectively). Real world data collated and analysed as part of the global rollout have shown that the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are highly effective vaccines, with 94-95 per cent effectiveness against symptomatic COVID-19 and up to 100 per cent effectiveness against severe disease and death. Data has also shown that only minor adverse experiences are noted with these vaccines, which is limited to swelling, pain and soreness at the injection site. To date, no new or confirmed safety signals have been reported for the mRNA vaccines.

Both vaccines retain efficacy against COVID-19 variants. The technology used in the mRNA vaccines mean they can be quickly adapted and manufactured to account for virus variants in the future if necessary.

Technology using mRNA has been in development for decades, with clinical trials in humans being conducted as early as 2011. The COVID-19 pandemic provided funding and opportunity for researchers who have been studying and working with mRNA vaccines to produce safe and effective vaccines.

The Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines use a fragment of mRNA to instruct the body to generate an immune response against COVID-19. The mRNA is broken down quickly by the body. It never enters the nucleus and cannot affect or combine with our DNA in any way to change our genetic code or the body's cells. Instead, COVID-19 mRNA vaccines teach the body's cells how to make a protein that triggers a specific immune response to protect against COVID-19. The vaccines work with the body's natural defences to develop immunity to disease, so the body is able to rapidly create its own antibodies to prevent disease if it encounters the virus in the future.

Australia's priority remains to vaccinate as many people as soon as possible, where the benefits of vaccination continue to outweigh any risks. This will reduce pressure on health care services, including hospitals and intensive care facilities and help to protect the health of Australians who are at higher risk of severe disease.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
NAPLAN: Eid al-Fitr
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 13 May 2021 regarding petition number EN2448. I note the petition requests changing the dates of the National Assessment Program - Literacy and Numeracy (NAPLAN) testing in 2021 as it coincides with Islamic festival Eid al-Fitr, marking the conclusion of Ramadan.

NAPLAN is held at the commencement of Term 2 each year. It is complex to schedule the NAPLAN testing window across the nation and this decision is made in collaboration with all jurisdictions and set many years in advance.

As Islamic special events and rituals are set by the lunar calendar, the dates for these events change from year to year. While this year's test event coincided with Ramadan, the proposed NAPLAN schedule for 2022-24 is outside of Ramadan and the start of Eid al-Fitr.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education and Youth, Mr Tudge
India

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021 enclosing Petition EN2449 concerning tensions in the Indian Australian community. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

I note that the three petitioners have alleged Indian Australian "separatist groups" are spreading disharmony within the Australian community. I also note the petitioners request that the House of Representatives cease any funding and permission to protest to these groups.

Australia is a prosperous and cohesive liberal democracy. We have one of the world's most tolerant and thriving multicultural societies. Present day Australia owes its strength and prosperity in no small part to the economic and social contributions of the successive generations of migrants coming to our shores.
As a nation, we are bound together by our shared values of freedom of religion, speech and association, commitment to the rule of law and parliamentary democracy, and equality and a fair go for all.

The Australian Government condemns hatred and vilification in all its forms. Everyone in the Australian community, regardless of their religious, ethnic or cultural background, has the right to feel safe, respected and included in our successful multicultural society.

Violence and assault are criminal offences and there are federal and state laws in place with significant penalties. If members of the public feel threatened or unsafe in any way, they should contact the following:
the police on 000 for immediate threats;
the local police on 13 14 44; or
Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

The Department of Home Affairs' grant programs are designed to meet all requirements of the Public Governance Performance Accountability Act 2013, and the Commonwealth Grant Rules and Guidelines. Applicants must demonstrate that they meet all eligibility requirements in order to apply for a grant. They must also demonstrate how funding will be used to achieve the funding outcomes described in the grant guidelines.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2449 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
National Education Standards
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email regarding Petition EN2452 - Human Evolution Education. In response to the issue raised in the petition I can provide the following advice.

The nationally agreed Foundation - Year 10 Australian Curriculum (the curriculum) sets the expectations for what all Australian students should be taught and is a key mechanism for providing educational consistency across the nation.

All Education Ministers have tasked the Australian Curriculum, Assessment and Reporting Authority (ACARA) with improving the curriculum by refining, realigning and decluttering the content. In doing this, ACARA draws on the expertise of curriculum and other experts, the teaching profession and stakeholders. A rigorous, balanced and evidenced based curriculum is an important contribution to lifting Australia's performance in literacy, numeracy and science.

ACARA is undertaking public consultation on the draft curriculum revisions from 29 April to 8 July 2021 and feedback from all stakeholders and the community is welcome. The petitioner may wish to participate in the consultation process. Further information about the review is at www.australiancurriculum.edu.au/consultation.

While the Australian Government takes a leadership role in matters of national education policy, the delivery of school education is a matter for State and Territory Government and non-government education authorities. The petitioner may wish to contact their State or Territory Education Minister to discuss their concerns. Contact details are enclosed.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education and Youth, Mr Tudge

Parliament
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition number EN2459.The petition relates to the content of one of the House of Representatives infosheets and refers to an earlier petition (EN1252), regarding communication with constituents.

The purpose of the infosheet series is to educate members of the public on the operation of the House and Parliament, and Australia's system of government. The series is maintained by the Department of the House of Representatives, for which I have oversight responsibility.

The House infosheet series is regularly reviewed and updated to ensure that information is current and, where necessary, reflects changes in House practice and procedure. Members of Parliament and their staff are not involved in this process, although it would be open to any Member to draw the attention of departmental staff to errors of fact.

The infosheet that is the subject of the petition, Infosheet 15: The work of a Member of Parliament, was last updated in March 2020. The department has advised that the changes made at this time were mostly stylistic in nature. The line that is referred to in petition EN1252—'communication skills are important in all aspects of a Member's work, but are particularly so in working with constituents'—remains under the heading 'What skills does a Member need?' on page 1.

Members are best placed to determine the most suitable way of communicating with their constituents, whether in person or online, and the management of social media accounts and other communication methods is a matter for them.

I trust this information will be of assistance to the petitioners. It is pleasing that members of the public are taking advantage of resources which provide information about the work of the House and its Members.
Sincerely
from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Tony Smith
Afghanistan
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 13 May 2021 regarding Petition Number EN2474. The petition requested

span.span: "the House to call on the Australian Government to publicly condemn the violence against Afghan human rights defenders, journalists, and media workers, and especially violence against Afghan women in these and other roles in society. We ask the Australian Government to increase its support to the Afghanistan Government by providing urgent and immediate protections for Afghanis in these roles and to protect their legitimate rights to life, freedom of expression, to access education, employment and other fundamental freedoms without fear of reprisal or attack."

p.span: I am pleased to provide further information regarding Australia's support to promote the rights of all Afghans, including Afghan women through our political advocacy, development assistance and support in multilateral fora. The Australian Government condemns in the strongest terms the ongoing violence, targeted killings, attacks, and other human rights abuses in Afghanistan.

During my visit to Kabul on 9 May 2021, I discussed the gains made by the people of Afghanistan over the past 20 years, the development and humanitarian assistance provided by Australia and our enduring shared commitment to a sustainable peace that is genuinely inclusive and involves all of Afghan society. I discussed these issues with the Acting Minister of Women's Affairs, Mrs Hasina Safi, as well as President Ghani.

Australia's former Embassy in Kabul contributed to several joint statements on social media @AusEmbAfg. These statements condemned the campaign of violence against media workers and journalists in Afghanistan. Australia will continue this work through other channels now that the Embassy has moved to non-residential accreditation.

Australia participated in the Group of Friends of Afghanistan and Group of Friends of Women in Afghanistan at the United Nations in New York. In March, we contributed to a joint statement condemning the continued violence and targeted killings. We also participated in the Heart of Asia- Istanbul Peace Conference in April 2021, where we called for an immediate end to the ongoing campaign of targeted assassinations and attacks on civilians, particularly the ongoing targeting of women and human rights activists and other prominent women such as judges and police officers.

The Australian Government has provided around $1.51 billion in official development assistance to Afghanistan since 2001. Australia was pleased to join the Geneva Ministerial Conference in November 2020 to reaffirm our commitment of support to the future development of Afghanistan. Australia pledged up to $200 million over 2021-2024, with $52.5 million this financial year.

Australia's Ending Violence Against Women Program ($22.5 million, 2012-21) is raising awareness on women's right s in Islam and Afghanistan's Law on the Elimination of Violence Against Women. Australia is supporting the training of community and faith leaders to challenge harmful gender norms in society and encourage women's engagement in political and economic affairs . The program's impact is demonstrating that better-informed religious and community leaders can become gender-conscious mediators and advocates for women's rights, and highlighting the crucial role of men and boys in combatting violence against women and girls.

Our Empowerment through Education program ($20.7 million, 2011-20), delivered by CARE Afghanistan, fills a gap in basic education across five Afghan provinces, particularly targeting girls in remote and rural communities. The program includes peace education, and new 'women, peace and security' curriculum currently under development.

Australian funding to UN Development Programme is promoting equitable and just dispute resolution mechanisms for Afghan women. This includes supporting an assessment of the prevalence of gender-based violence across Afghanistan during COVID-19 lockdown, and piloting innovative approaches to target the root causes of family violence and increasing survivors' access to support services.

The Australian Government remains committed to supporting the peace process in Afghanistan and acknowledges there is no military solution to the longstanding conflict . An Afghan-led and owned political settlement is the only way to resolve the conflict and maintain the gains of the past 20 years. Australia will continue to support these gains through political advocacy, development assistance and support in multilateral fora.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021 enclosing Petition EN2485 concerning allowing extended family members of Australians who have received the COVID-19 vaccine to travel to Australia. Your correspondence was referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.
As you know, Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia.

At the present time, there is no exception to Australia's travel restrictions policy settings as a result of an individual's vaccination status or the vaccination programs which are becoming available in several jurisdictions overseas.

The Australian Government regularly reviews Australia's travel restrictions policy as national and global circumstances in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic evolve, and is guided by the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee in relation to easing restrictions on international travel.
Implementing any changes to the current policy settings for travel restrictions and exempting travellers based on their vaccination status will be a process informed by expert health advice.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at:
https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2485 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Commonwealth Electoral Act
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 13 May 2021 referring to petition number EN2487, which requests that the voting age be lowered to 16 years of age. I am responding as the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters.

It is important that the right to vote applies from an appropriate age, to ensure that electors can adequately understand parliamentary representation, enrolment and the electoral process. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 provides that persons aged 16 years and over may enrol provisionally, ahead of becoming eligible to vote when they are 18 years of age. This is one way of encouraging people to start thinking about their future rights and responsibilities as voters, before they become qualified to vote.

Young people who have an interest in politics can also participate in public debates in various ways including by making submissions to parliamentary committees or by writing to members of Parliament. The Government also provides funding for a range of educational programs and resources, including the Museum of Australian Democracy, to help young Australians build their understanding of how Australia's system of government works.

The Government has no plans to change the voting age, noting that while 16- and 17-year­ olds do take on significant responsibilities, in most cases this is under parental guidance. Voting, like most other social and legal norms does not and should not apply full responsibility until the age of 18.
Thank you for bringing the matters referred to in this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, Mr Morton
Circumcision
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 13 May 2021 concerning Petition Number EN2490, presented to the House of Representatives on 12 May 2021.

The petition called for a ban on circumcision of all children, boys and girls. The Australian Government cannot support a blanket ban on circumcision, as there are circumstances in which it is both appropriate and necessary for a male to undergo the procedure. Information concerning circumcision and the situations where it is appropriate to be performed on health grounds is provided at: www.healthdirect.gov.au/male-circumcision.

The Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) currently provides benefits to patients for circumcision of the penis (MBS Items 30658 and 30654). The Health Insurance Act 1973, stipulates that Medicare benefits are only payable for clinically relevant services provided by health practitioners. A clinically relevant service is one that is generally accepted by the relevant profession as necessary for the appropriate treatment of the patient.

The government relies on the judgement of health practitioners to determine whether medical services are clinically relevant and meet the MBS item descriptor requirements in deciding whether a procedure is necessary for a particular patient, including infants.

Medical professional groups such as the Royal Australasian College of Physicians, the Australasian Association of Paediatric Surgeons, the Australian Medical Association and the Australian Paediatric Association do not support routine male circumcision except where it is clinically relevant and there is an identified need for surgery to improve the patient's health. The policy statements from these organisations and other jurisdictions can be found at: www.cirp.org/library/statements.

You may be interested to know that some states (such as New South Wales and Victoria) have policies that circumcision on infants does not routinely occur in public hospitals. Data is publicly available for services funded under the MBS, however, there is no specific register related to circumcision.
With regard to female circumcision, this is illegal in Australia. It is also illegal to take female children overseas for this procedure.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Remembrance Day
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 13 May 2021 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, enclosing petition EN2502, which requests the Commonwealth Government declare a National Day of Remembrance for COVID-19 on 26 October 2021. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf.

National days may be observed without a proclamation or intervention by the Australian Government. A number of days throughout the year have gained community acceptance as the dates on which particular events are celebrated or commemorated. These events generally evolve without government involvement. Examples include Mothers' Day and Red Nose Day. The proclamation of 'days of national observance' by the Governor-General is one of a number of ways to promote the observation of days of celebration or commemoration.

The Government has acknowledged the response to the COVID-19 crisis has been unprecedented, both on the front-line and behind the scenes. Suitably the focus for the Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments is the health and wellbeing of Australians, their livelihoods, their jobs and ensuring Australia is positioned to emerge strong and robust.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
Mental Health
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 May 2021 concerning petition number EN2515. The petition requests a Royal Commission into Australian Defence Force (ADF) members and veteran suicide as well as depression.

As you will be aware, on 19 April 2021 the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, announced the Australian Government's intention to establish a Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide from 1 July 2021.

The Royal Commission is expected to examine the systemic issues and any common themes in past deaths by suicide of ADF members and veterans and the experience of members and veterans who may continue to be at risk of suicide. This includes all aspects of service in the ADF and the experience of those transitioning; the availability and quality of health and support services; pre-service and post-service issues for members and veterans; members' and veterans' social and family contexts, such as family breakdown, as well as housing and employment issues for members and veterans.

The Prime Minister asked me to lead a public consultation process around these themes to inform the Terms of Reference for the Royal Commission. This consultation period has now closed and I have provided feedback to the Attorney-General, Senator the Hon Michaelia Cash, to lead the process for the drafting of the Letters Patent for the establishment of the Royal Commission. ADF members, veterans and their families, as well as other interested stakeholders, were also able to provide feedback directly to the Attorney-General's Department through its website.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I hope this information is of assistance to
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Personnel, Mr Chester
Australian Courts
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 May 2021 regarding House of Representatives petition EN2521 requesting that the House ensure that the "special witness" feature/status offered to a female is removed to ensure parity in the legal framework.

Vulnerable witness protections are designed to support complainants in certain matters to provide evidence in court proceedings and include use of pre-recorded testimony and closed-circuit television to give evidence and restrictions on cross-examination in certain circumstances. These measures support complainants to present their best possible testimony and reduce the risk that complainants will be re-traumatised while giving evidence. They do not affect the weight that is given to evidence by the trier of fact, nor do they remove a defendant's right to challenge that evidence. The availability of vulnerable witness protections is not limited by the gender of the complainant. Men and women are equally entitled to vulnerable witness protections provided that certain requirements are met.

At the Commonwealth level, vulnerable witness protections are available to children and adult complainants involved in specified proceedings (slavery, trafficking arid child sex abuse offences in respect of children complaints; slavery and trafficking offences in respect of adult complainants) and to 'special witnesses' in respect of proceedings for any Commonwealth offence. A person may be declared a special witness if the court is satisfied that the person is unlikely to be able to satisfactorily give evidence in the ordinary manner because of a disability or because of intimidation, distress or emotional trauma.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Health Care
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 24 May 2021 enclosing petition EN2523, concerning the Australian Government's investment in Australia's public health system.

The Australian Government believes that a mixed model of balanced private and public health services is integral to the provision of universal access to high quality, affordable health care services for all Australians.

Australia's health system is one of the best in the world and strives to provide safe and affordable high quality care for every Australian. While our health system performs well, there is a need to ensure the health system continues to meet changing health needs in a flexible and sustainable manner, to achieve the best outcomes for the Australian population now and into the future.

The 2020-25 National Health Reform Agreement (NHRA) was agreed by the Australian Government with all state and territory governments on 29 May 2020, and commenced on 1 July 2020. The NHRA sets out the financial and governance arrangements for Australia's public hospital system for the next five years. It also includes a shared commitment by all Australian governments to long-term system-wide health reforms to improve health outcomes for all Australians, and create a more efficient and sustainable health system.

The NHRA recognises the states and territories as system managers of their public hospital systems, with responsibility for delivering emergency Department, admitted and non-admitted care, and other services (for example, specialist, mental health and sub-acute care). As system managers, the states and territories are responsible for determining the mix of the services and functions delivered within their jurisdiction, and for system-wide public hospital service planning and performance.

As part of the NHRA, the state and territory governments have committed to providing eligible patients with the choice to receive public hospital services free-of-charge, on the basis of clinical need and within a clinically appropriate period. States have also committed to have arrangements in place to ensure equitable access to such services, regardless of geographical location.
Through the NHRA, the Australian Government is providing a record funding contribution to assist states and territories with the costs of delivering public hospital services.

The Australian Government's funding contribution for public hospitals services in all states and territories under the NHRA has grown substantially from $13.3 billion in 2012-13 to $25.5 billion in 2019-20, or by 92 per cent. Funding under the 2020-25 NHRA is projected to continue to grow to $135.4 billion between 2020-21 and 2024-25. This funding will mean more doctors, more nurses and importantly more services and support for patients.

In addition, the Australian Government is investing $1.25 billion through the Community Health and Hospitals Program to fund projects and services in every state and territory, supporting patient care while reducing pressure on community and hospital services.

The NHRA builds on the collaboration between the Australian Government and the states and territories in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic, ensuring the Australian health system remains stable and nationally coordinated, particularly throughout this unprecedented time.
The 2020-25 NHRA signals a commitment by all governments to work together to implement long-term system-wide health reforms, in line with the following strategic priority areas:
improving efficiency and ensuring financial sustainability
delivering safe, high-quality care in the right place at the right time
prioritising prevention and helping people manage their health across their lifetime
driving best practice and performance using data and research.

The reforms will deliver greater flexibility that will make it easier to provide high-quality, person-centred care in the most appropriate setting, reduce avoidable hospitalisations, and improve system sustainability.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Charitable Organisations
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 May 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2526, which requests that the Basic Religious Charity category and exemptions in the Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission Act 2012 (the ACNC Act) be abolished. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

As noted in the petition, some religious entities registered with the Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission (ACNC) can be designated as a 'basic religious charity'. This results in fewer reporting and other obligations under the ACNC Act. Basic religious charities are not required to provide financial information as part of their Annual Information Statements, submit annual financial reports, or comply with the governance standards.

The definition of a basic religious charity was incorporated into the ACNC Act in part to reflect the concepts of religious freedom in the Australian Constitution and under international human rights laws. The exemptions granted to basic religious charities are intended to reduce the governance and compliance requirements placed on small religious bodies which are not incorporated and receive little direct funds from government.

An organisation must meet strict eligibility requirements to be registered as a basic religious charity.
