This includes, among other criteria, that the organisation is registered only with the charitable purpose of advancing religion and not any other subtype, that it is not a deductible gift recipient, and that the total grants it receives from Australian government agencies in a financial year does not exceed $100,000.

I would like to emphasise the Australian Government's commitment to ensuring that children are safe and protected from abuse. The Australian Government is currently working to implement its response to the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse (the Royal Commission), which investigated how institutions and governments can better protect children, how they can achieve best practice in reporting and responding to incidents and how to address the impact of child sexual abuse.

As part of its response, the Government established the National Redress Scheme to ensure that people who experienced institutional child sexual abuse receive redress through financial payments, counselling and psychological care. The Government has taken specific steps to ensure that all charities, including basic religious charities, are accountable under the scheme. On 25 February 2021, a new ACNC governance standard came into effect which requires registered charities to take reasonable steps to join the Scheme if an application has been made or is likely to be made against them. Alongside this governance standard, the Government amended the ACNC Act to require basic religious charities with an application made against them to join the Redress Scheme. Basic religious charities that fail to meet this requirement will lose their status and exemptions under the ACNC Act, and then be subject to all ACNC governance standards, including the new governance standard.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I refer to your correspondence of 24 May 2021 to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, the Hon Michael McCormack MP, enclosing petition EN2543 concerning seeking travel exemptions for parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents to travel to Australia. Your correspondence was referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As outlined in the correspondence to you of 25 January 2021 from the former Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Peter Dutton MP, in response to Petition EN1860 Inclusion of Parents as "Immediate" family members for travel exemption, and my correspondence to you of 25 May 2021 in response to Petition EN2311 Include parents as immediate family members for travel exemption, currently no consideration is being given to broaden the definition of immediate family and automatically exempt parents from the travel restrictions for travel to Australia.

Individuals, including parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents, who are not automatically exempt from the travel restrictions but have a compelling reason to travel to Australia, can submit a travel exemption request for an assessment against the exemption categories outlined on the Department of Home Affairs' website at:
https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions.

An exemption request should be accompanied by the individual's details, case information and supporting statement and can be submitted through the online portal on the Department's website at: https://travel-exemptions.homeaffairs.gov.au/tep.

Decisions to grant exemptions must be balanced against the Government's intent for imposing the travel restrictions, that is, the potential health risks posed to the Austral ian community by international travellers.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2543 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Federal Election
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter dated 24 May 2021 regarding petition EN2544, which proposes that a federal election is held immediately. I am responding as the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters.

As you would be aware, under the Australian Constitution, the House of Representatives may sit for a maximum of three years from the first meeting of the House after a federal election, but may be dissolved sooner. Senators are elected for six-year terms on a rotating membership, with half of the Senators being elected every three years. Newly-elected Senators commence their six-year term on 1 July, with half-Senate elections required to be held within one year before the places of the Senators become vacant.

Generally, half-Senate elections are held concurrently with elections for the House of Representatives. Noting that half of the current Senators' terms are due to expire on 30 June 2022, the next federal election (simultaneous half-Senate and House of Representatives election) may be called as early as Saturday 7 August 2021, or as late as Saturday 22 May 2022. The Governor-General may call a federal election, on the advice of the Prime Minister, through issuing a formal order (writ) for the election. However, the Governor-General may not call an election outside of the timeframes outlined above, except in the case of a double dissolution election. Consequently, the Government cannot call an immediate election, as the petitioners suggest.

However, I would like to assure the petitioners that, when the next federal election is called in accordance with the requirements outlined above, it will be conducted within the legislated timeframes. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (the Electoral Act) governs the timing of different aspects of the election following the issue of the writs, such as the final date for the nomination of candidates.

I note the petitioners also request the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) be provided with powers to prevent and prosecute ineligible, unlawful or misleading incidents in the lead-up to an election, and disqualify parties or candidates that are party to any such incidents. The AEC already has powers to prosecute activities which are prohibited under the Electoral Act, as well as administering the Act's requirements for candidate and political party eligibility. Moreover, illegal activities not covered under the Electoral Act are captured under the Criminal Code Act 1995 (the Criminal Code). The existing provisions in the Electoral Act and the Criminal Code ensure that the AEC and other government entities can appropriately respond to unlawful election-related incidents.
The Government takes political freedoms seriously, and considers the rights of Australians to engage in our electoral system imperative to the functioning of Australia's democracy.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
from the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, Mr Morton
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 24 May 2021 concerning petition number EN2557.
EN2557 concerns the same topic and request that was addressed in my response to petition number PN0504. I have enclosed a copy of that response for your convenience.

My response remains unchanged. In essence, there is a legislated process for seeking a change to the Statements of Principles (SOPs). This is for an eligible person to contact the Repatriation Medical Authority (RMA) to request an investigation of the sound scientific and medical evidence regarding the causation of a condition. The Government cannot direct the RMA to include specific factors in the SOPs, nor would it be appropriate to do so. Should an RMA investigation conclude there is sound medical and scientific evidence to include a factor, then the relevant Statement of Principle(s) will be amended. The RMA can be contacted by email at info @rma.gov.au , by telephone on (07) 3815 9404 or via online feedback form at www.rma.gov.au/contact-us.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Personnel, Mr Chester
Olympic and Paralympic Games
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 24 May 2021about Petition EN2572 regarding concerns about a range of Chinese government actions, particularly reports of human rights abuses. The petition called for support for the removal of the 2022 Winter Olympics from Beijing and for a boycott by the Australian Olympic team.

The Australian Government is deeply concerned about the human rights situation in China, especially in regards to Hong Kong, Tibet and Xinjiang. We raise these concerns regularly, both directly with the Chinese government, and in appropriate international forums including at ministerial level.

Notwithstanding those concerns, as the Minister for Sport, Senator the Hon Richard Colbeck, has said, the Australian Government is not supporting calls for an athlete boycott of the 2022 Winter Olympic and Paralympic Games. Responsibility for sending teams to the Olympic and Paralympic Games rests solely with the independent Australian Olympic Committee and Paralympics Australia. Preparing for the Olympic and Paralympic Games is a lifelong endeavour for many athletes, and those who qualify should have the opportunity to compete.

Owing to the short amount of time between now and the start of the 2022 Winter Games, we do not believe it is feasible to relocate the Games away from Beijing. Having hosted the 1956 and 2000 Summer Games, we understand the level of commitment and preparation that would be required by any prospective host country.

The promotion and protection of human rights around the world are a matter of high priority for the government. We have a range of avenues available to advocate for improvements to the human rights situation in China and will continue to pursue these wherever appropriate.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Commonwealth Electoral Act
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 24 May 2021 regarding petition EN2574, which proposes mandatory voter identification and additional restrictions with respect to postal voting. I am responding as the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters.

The Government is committed to strengthening the integrity of our electoral system, and maintaining voter confidence in elections. While mandatory voter identification could be one method to provide additional confidence, such a policy would require legislative amendment, and appears unlikely to attract bipartisan support at this time.

As part of the 2020-21 Budget, the Government has provided $96.7 million over three years to commence the modernisation of the Australian Electoral Commissions' (AEC) ICT systems and infrastructure, to protect the integrity of federal elections and improve services to Australian voters. Further funding of $26.8 million was also provided in December 2020 to support the continued rollout of Electronic Certified Lists, which allow polling booths across the country to communicate in real-time. This ensures voters marked off the roll in one area are prevented from voting again elsewhere, catching out instances of multiple-voting in federal elections.

Regarding the petitioners' request to restrict postal voting, I note the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (the Electoral Act) already contains provisions outlining the grounds of application for a postal vote. These include instances where an individual is unable to attend a polling booth due to serious illness or residing overseas, as the petitioners suggest. The existing provisions in the Electoral Act ensure that postal voting is only available under specific circumstances.

The Government is considering the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters report into the conduct of the 2019 federal election, which includes recommendations relevant to the matters of voter identification and postal voting raised by the petitioners. The Government will provide a full response to each of the recommendations in due course.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, Mr Morton
Superannuation
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition (EN2583) signed by one person. This petition is seeking a mandatory requirement for all superannuation funds to disclose how human overpopulation risk may affect superannuation returns and how funds are managing these risks.

The licensee of a registerable superannuation entity (licensee) is required to have a risk management framework in place that covers all material risks, both financial and non-financial. Licensees are responsible for identifying these risks. This framework must enable the licensee to develop and implement strategies, policies, procedures and controls to appropriately manage different types of material risk.

The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA), which is the entity responsible for regulating this aspect of a superannuation fund's operations, recently released draft guidance on how licensees should manage the financial risks associated with climate change (see Prudential Practice Guide: Draft CPG 229 Climate Change Financial Risks). The draft guidance is available from the APRA website: www.apra.gov.au.

If a member of a superannuation fund wants information on an issue relating to the fund, such as how the fund is managing a particular risk, the member can ask that question at the Annual Members' Meeting for the fund. A responsible officer of the licensee must answer that question at the meeting or within one month after the meeting. In addition, the minutes of the meeting must include the answer to that question.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and the Digital Economy, Senator Hume
National Education Standards
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 24 May 2021 regarding Petition number EN2584. The petition requests inclusion of environmental concerns as part of the relationships and sexuality module of the Australian Curriculum.

The nationally agreed Foundation - Year 10 Australian Curriculum (the curriculum), endorsed by all Education Ministers, sets the expectations for what all Australian students should be taught, regardless of where they live or their background. Year 7 students are given the opportunity to learn about population growth as it relates to food production as part of the Physical and Environmental Geography sub-strand of the Geography learning area.

In 2015, Education Ministers agreed a regular review of the curriculum should occur every six years. The last review occurred in 2014. On 12 June 2020, all Education Ministers agreed to the Terms of Reference for the current review to ensure the curriculum remains current and continues to meet the needs of students in line with the Alice Springs (Mparntwe) Education Declaration. A rigorous, balanced and evidenced based curriculum is an important contribution to lifting Australia's performance in literacy, numeracy and science.

Ministers have tasked the Australian Curriculum, Assessment and Reporting Authority (ACARA) to refine, realign and declutter the content of the curriculum. In doing this ACARA draws on the expertise of curriculum experts, the teaching profession and stakeholders. ACARA is undertaking public consultation from 29 April to 8 July 2021 and feedback from all stakeholders and the community is welcome. I encourage the signatories of this petition to participate in the consultation process. Further information about the review including how you can submit your feedback is at www.australiancurriculum.edu.au/consultation.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education and Youth, Mr Tudge
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter of 24 May 2021 concerning petition number EN2585 regarding a request that Gold Cards be provided to veterans covered by the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation (Defence-related Claims) Act 1988 (DRCA).

The veteran Gold Card provides for treatment for all health conditions, whether or not they are related to service. It is an entitlement which is targeted towards meeting the health needs of those eligible current and former Australian Defence Force members whose service has caused, or has an acknowledged higher likelihood of causing, significant health problems. This includes those veterans who served on active operations against an enemy during a war or conflict, and those who have a high level of disability caused by their service.

Eligibility for the Gold Card exists under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA) and the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 (MRCA) and is also available to Australian participants in British Nuclear Testing and members of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization medical teams in Vietnam . The DRCA differs from the VEA and the MRCA, as it only provides treatment and compensation for conditions accepted as being related to service . It currently makes no provision for the treatment of any non-service-related injuries and diseases. As such, there is no legislative basis under the DRCA to issue the Gold Card, even where a veteran has a high level of service-related impairment.

The 2019 Productivity Commission report, A Better Way to Support Veterans, made recommendations about bringing certain aspects of DRCA entitlements and eligibility in line with the other Acts administered by the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA). As was noted in the Government's interim response to the Productivity Commission report, these recommendations, which focus on simplifying and harmonising legislation, processes and benefits will be important considerations as OVA continues to improve the accessibility, simplicity, and continuity of support for veterans and their families.

However, the Productivity Commission also specifically recommended against providing a Gold Card under DRCA. While the Government's interim response to the Productivity Commission rejected the recommendation that there be no further expansion of Gold Card eligibility, any change to provide a Gold Card to veterans covered under the DRCA will require passage of legislation. The cost implications of such a change would require Government consideration in a Budget context .
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Chester
Foreign Investment
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 May 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2594 - foreign ownership of Australian land. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Foreign investment provides significant benefits to Australia. It is important for economic growth and job creation, and it contributes to the prosperity of businesses, communities, and the overall economy. Without foreign investment, Australia's production, employment, and income would all be lower.
At the same time, the Government recognises that foreign investments must be in the national interest.

Foreign investment into Australia, including foreign acquisitions of land, is managed through Australia's foreign investment review framework. This framework strikes a balance between ensuring we remain an attractive investment destination and upholding the national interest so that Australians can be confident in the benefits of foreign investment. If it is determined that a proposed investment is contrary to Australia's national interest, it will not be approved or conditions will be applied to safeguard the national interest.

Comprehensive reforms to the foreign investment review framework also came into effect from 1 January 2021. These reforms update the framework in three broad ways: they address national security risks; strengthen the existing system, particularly as it relates to compliance by foreign investors; and streamline investment in non-sensitive businesses.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 24 May 2021 concerning petition number EN2598 requesting the Australian Government remove the mandatory influenza vaccination requirement to visit residential aged care facilities.

States and territories established directions under their emergency management provisions in response to COVID-19, which set out requirements with regard to visitors to and entry into residential aged care facilities. The directions give effect to the recommendations of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC), endorsed by National Cabinet.

The entry restrictions generally apply to individuals entering a residential aged care facility, including staff, visitors, health practitioners, volunteers and others. There are differences and exemptions across the jurisdictions regarding when an influenza vaccination is available to a person. Broadly speaking however there are no exemptions to the influenza vaccination requirements for individuals that choose not to be vaccinated for personal, cultural or religious reasons.

The directions are temporary, established under individual jurisdictions' emergency management provisions in response to COVID-19. It is a matter for the individual state and territory governments to update, extend or repeal the directions/Public Health Orders in response to the evolving COVID-19 situation.
Jurisdictions have published supporting information, for individuals to understand how the directions apply to their personal circumstances.

In relation to the legality of state and territory directions, there is an array of statutory powers that can be exercised in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic. The key statutes which confer these types of powers for use in the current circumstances are powers that are conferred under various Public Health and Biosecurity statutes.

The Government is a strong supporter of immunisation in that it is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

While noting that states and territories have established entry restrictions to residential aged care facilities for individuals that do not meet certain vaccination requirements, immunisation is not compulsory and people maintain the right to choose whether to receive an influenza vaccination. It is recommended that employees discuss specific vaccination requirements with their employer.

Vaccines are only made available in Australia and included on the National Immunisation Program after they have been rigorously tested, evaluated and approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration to ensure they meet stringent safety and efficacy guidelines. Vaccines continue to be tested after their introduction via additional clinical trials, surveillance and monitoring of vaccine adverse events.

With regard to mandatory COVID-19 vaccinations, residential aged care workers and residents are a priority and have been among the first people in Australia to receive the COVID-19 vaccine. On 22 January 2021, the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, announced that National Cabinet had agreed the AHPPC interim advice that state and territory public health orders should not be utilised to require vaccination against COVID-19 for residential aged care facilities.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 24 May 2021 concerning Petition EN2605 - introduction of statutory timeframe on deciding Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA) claims and applications.

The introduction of statutory timeframes for determining claims under veterans and other compensation legislation has been examined in the past. A number of reviews have concluded that statutory timeframes would not produce better outcomes for veterans and may deliver unintended consequences. These reviews include (but are not limited to):
In June 2014, the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission released a report into the 'Review of Statutory Timeframes under the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 (MRCA)'.
Discussion of the use of statutory timeframes under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Amendment (Improving the Comcare Scheme) Bill 2015.
Most recently the 2019 Productivity Commission report "A Better Way to Support Veterans" which did not support the establishment of statutory timeframes.

These reviews have generally concluded that statutory timeframes lead to adverse, unexpected and inequitable outcomes, and are generally detrimental to veterans. Defined timeframes to decide claims may result in a number of adverse outcomes, including poor and incorrect decisions being made.

The petition notes that the Australian Veterans' Recognition (Putting Veterans and Their Families First) Act 2019 includes a 90 day commitment for the determination of claims under the MRCA. This aspirational goal, which does not represent a statutory timeframe, recognises that claims will be decided in a time that is proportionate to the complexity of the matter. Because of the varied complexity of claims there will always be differences in timeliness of decision making.
There are a number of factors which can result in delays in processing a claim. As well as the number of claims on hand, the time taken to determine claims can be influenced by the following:
The time between an incident or a veteran's service and the subsequent lodgement of a claim, which may make accessing relevant evidence difficult.
The complexity of the claim (for instance whether the relevant service is covered under one or multiple Acts or the number of conditions lodged with the claim).
The need to obtain further information from the veteran, the Australian Defence Force, medical practitioners or witnesses.
Many of these factors are outside the control of the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA).

A defined timeframe in which to determine a claim is likely to create additional pressures on delegates, which could impact on the quality of decision making. It would also require others involved in the process, such as medical practitioners, to prioritise the provision of claim information, potentially at the expense of providing timely health care for the benefit of veterans.
In addition, the potential consequences for not meeting a defined statutory timeframe will also create difficulties:

An automatic rejection after a set period has elapsed may disadvantage veterans (although it is acknowledged that this would encourage submission of complete and detailed claims with relevant supporting evidence).

This option was considered and rejected by Parliament in the context of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Amendment (Improving the Comcare Scheme) Bill 2015 on the basis that it would require a client to contest a mandated rejection through relevant appeals processes, including the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the courts.
It may also create perverse incentives for delegates to finalise claims without adequately investigating a claim or obtaining the relevant evidence, resulting in incorrect outcomes.
An automatic acceptance may lead to inconsistent outcomes for veterans in the same circumstances, regardless of the evidence or merits of a case.

The Productivity Commission noted that this could create perverse incentives among veterans to submit incomplete, incorrect or late information in order to ensure the timeframe elapses before a claim can be determined.

This could also mean that weak claims that should not otherwise succeed would be determined favourably and more complex (or historical) cases where there is a lack of evidence available or easily accessible will by default succeed, which could again lead to inequitable outcomes.
In the case of automatic acceptance the approach could also result in unnecessary (and potentially large) debts arising where a subsequent review finds the veteran is ineligible for a benefit.

Set timeframes may also make it more likely that claims would be determined without consideration of the full merits of the case and result in inequitable outcomes among clients with similar circumstances. Even without a defined outcome, set timeframes could create a situation where, due to time pressures, claims may be accepted where they should be rejected and rejected where they should be accepted. This would not conform with the intent of the legislation, which is to arrive at the correct or preferable outcome on the basis of the available evidence and in accordance with the relevant statutory tests.

For these reasons, set timeframes may result in higher error rates and require veterans to pursue the proper entitlements through prolonged, stressful and potentially unnecessary appeals processes. Ultimately, this could result in increased time taken to finalise a claim.

Importantly, the Government has taken numerous steps to mitigate the impact of claim determination times on veterans and eligible dependants. For example, the Government has introduced the Veteran Payment, a temporary payment providing financial support while mental health claims are being assessed. The trial of provisional access to medical treatment for the top 20 claimed conditions while these claims are being assessed has recently been extended. Policy initiatives have also led to a reduction in the time taken to process claims through the streamlining and straight-through-processing of certain conditions.

Due to the Government's significant reforms in recent years encouraging engagement with DVA, raising awareness of the right to claim and making it easier for veterans to do so, claims have more than doubled between the financial years 2017-18 to 2019-20. This has created a backlog. The Government is committed to managing this backlog and has provided DVA with more than $98 million through the 2021-22 Budget to fund additional resources to attend to the increased workload. These combined initiatives will see an increase to DVA's staffing by more than 440 positions - the largest increase to DVA resourcing in decades. This demonstrates the Government's commitment to reducing the claims backlog and reducing the time taken to determine a claim.
Thank you for taking the time to write.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Chester
Women's Economic Security
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 24 May 2021 regarding petition number EN2607 requesting the introduction of a Bill to legislate for measures relating to the gender pay gap.

The Australian Government strongly believes that the best way to address the gender pay gap is through the government, business and the community all taking action on this issue. In particular, the Government is focused on ensuring the gains made by women in recent years, including a record-low gender pay gap of 13.4 per cent in November 2020, are not reversed by the economic and social effects of COVID-19.
The Government is taking action to address the issue of the gender pay gap and to support families through:
a range of measures in the 2018 and 2020 Women's Economic Security Statements that support women's workforce participation and close the gender pay gap;
the 2021-22 Women's Budget Statement, which provides a $3.4 billion investment towards women's safety, economic security, health and wellbeing; and
ensuring families dealing with the trauma of stillbirth, premature birth or the death of their child during unpaid parental leave are able to take the unpaid parental leave they had planned to take.

The Government committed a range of measures in the 2018 and 2020 Women's Economic Security Statements to support women's workforce participation and close the gender pay gap. The Statements include a wide range of measures to create new jobs, support more women into work, expand opportunities for business and build the skills Australia needs to support accelerated economic recovery and growth.

The2021-22 Women's Budget Statement provides a $3.4 billion investment towards women's safety, economic security, health and wellbeing. The Government is further investing in new arid expanded initiatives to provide practical and effective support to increase women's workforce participation, reduce barriers to women working in the paid workforce and assist women to build a financially secure future.

Under the National Employment Standards of the Fair Work Act 2009 (Fair Work Act), parental leave and related entitlements provide minimum leave entitlements for all employees covered by the national system.

In November 2020, the Fair Work Amendment (Improving Unpaid Parental Leave for Parents of Stillborn Babies and Other Measures) Act 2020 was passed to ensure that families dealing with the trauma of stillbirth, premature birth or the death of their child during unpaid parental leave are able to take the unpaid parental leave they had planned to take without having to worry about returning to work before they are ready to do so.

The Government has zero tolerance for violence against women and children. In December 2018, the Coalition passed historic legislation enshrining five days' unpaid family and domestic violence leave in the Fair Work Act's National Employment Standards. This followed the independent Fair Work Commission's decision to grant five days of unpaid family and domestic violence leave to employees covered by a modern award.

The Fair Work Commission is reviewing the family and domestic violence leave clause in modern awards. Further consideration of the issue of paid leave will be appropriately informed by the Commission's consideration of the issue. Employers of course remain free to provide entitlements that suit their workplaces, and the Government commends initiatives of large employers in providing paid domestic violence leave.

The Fair Work Act is the legislation governing the employee and employer relationship in Australia and includes the objective of equal remuneration for work of equal or comparable value as part of the principles relating to the 'safety net' of minimum wages and conditions. The Fair Work Act also includes a specific provision for the making of Equal Remuneration Orders to ensure that, for employees to whom the order will apply, there will be equal remuneration for work of equal or comparable value.

The Workplace Gender Equality Agency continues to promote gender pay equity in organisations through a range of mechanisms, including: annual gender reporting; resources such as conducting a gender pay gap audit and developing a gender pay equity strategy; and through awareness campaigns and partnerships programs including the Pay Equity Ambassador network.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cash
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 24 May 2021 concerning petition number EN2609.

Before a prescription medicine (including a COVID-19 vaccine) can be legally supplied in Australia, the Therapeutics Goods Administration (TGA) rigorously assesses the safety, quality and effectiveness to determine if the benefits outweigh the risks.

The TGA prepares and publishes Australian Public Assessment Reports (AusPARs) for prescription medicines (including vaccines) that provide information about the evaluation of a medicine and the considerations that led the TGA to approve, or not approve, an application and subsequent use of that medicine or vaccine. AusPARs will be published for COVID-19 vaccines evaluated by the TGA. Further information is available on the TGA's website at: www.tga.gov.au/ws-auspar-index.

After product registration, the TGA has an important role in batch-release assessment and post-market surveillance to ensure the ongoing safety of the vaccine. Vaccines continue to be tested after their approval for use via additional clinical trials, surveillance and monitoring for adverse events. Further information is available at: www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines.

The Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) and the Thrombosis and Haemostasis Society of Australia and New Zealand (THANZ) are closely monitoring local and international data on the very rare and newly identified condition associated with COVID-19 Vaccine AstraZeneca called thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS) or vaccine induced thrombotic thrombocytopenia (VITT).
TTS is a rare condition with a different mechanism to most other causes of thrombosis and/or thrombocytopenia. Among case reports, there are no known markers for increased risk for TTS.

TTS is different from other blood clotting conditions and is triggered by the immune system's response to the COVID-19 Vaccine AstraZeneca. It results in both thrombosis and low platelet levels. In the majority of cases, pathological antibodies against platelet factor 4 (PF4), a protein released from platelets, are detected. Studies are ongoing to better understand the exact mechanism of TTS. TTS has been reported in patients who have received the AstraZeneca and Janssen COVID-19 vaccines (the latter is not used in Australia).
At this time, you are not able to choose which vaccine you receive. The ATAGI has recommended the AstraZeneca vaccine for most of the adult population 50 years and older, including:
people with a past history of venous thromboembolism in typical sites, such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism
people with a predisposition to form blood clots, such as those with Factor V Leiden, or other non-immune thrombophilic disorders
people with a family history of clots or clotting conditions
people currently receiving anticoagulant medications
people with a history of ischaemic heart disease or cerebrovascular accident
people with a current or past history of thrombocytopenia.
Pfizer is the preferred vaccine for:
people aged under 50 years, since the risk of TTS, albeit very low, appears to be higher in younger adults.
Pfizer is also recommended for people aged 16 years and above with:
a past history of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST)
a past history of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)
a past history of idiopathic splanchnic (mesenteric, portal and splenic) venous thrombosis
anti-phospholipid syndrome with thrombosis
a history of certain reactions to the AstraZeneca vaccine, for example:
anaphylaxis to a previous dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine, or to an ingredient of the vaccine
Thrombosis with thrombocytopenia occurring after the first dose of AstraZeneca vaccine
other serious adverse events attributed to the first dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine.
ATAGI considers that the benefits of the AstraZeneca vaccine for use in people 50 years and over outweigh the risks, if they do not have any of the conditions listed above.
TTS can now be treated very effectively. THANZ have developed guidance on identification and treatment of TTS, which is available on their website at: www.thanz.org.au/documents/item/590.

Getting vaccinated is voluntary. Once everyone under 50 years old has been offered two doses of the Pfizer vaccine, any remaining doses will be made available to those who have not yet been vaccinated. However, this may not happen until much later in the year. The Government encourages everyone to be vaccinated as soon as they are eligible.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Migration
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 enclosing Petition PN0494 concerning the impacts of migration on Australia's economy and infrastructure. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Over the past 40 years , Australia has enjoyed strong economic performance, underpinned by a growing population. This economic success has greatly enhanced our quality of life. Average incomes have doubled in real terms since 1975, with this increased wealth shared broadly across the community. As a result, Australian families enjoy access to a well-functioning health system, good schools, a strong social safety net and options for recreation and leisure.

Population growth has two main components: natural increase; and net overseas migration (NOM). Since the year ending June 2006, NOM has been a key driver of Australia's population growth, labour force participation rates and GDP.

COVID-19 has had significant impacts on migration to Australia. NOM has been affected by international travel restrictions and weaker labour markets domestically and globally. Treasury forecasts in the 2021-22 Budget indicate that NOM will move to a net outflow of -97,000 by the end of 2020-21. This will be the first time that NOM has been a net outflow since 1946.

We know that carefully targeted migration will be a key component of Australia's economic recovery. The 2021-22 Migration Program will retain the existing policy settings put in place for the 2020-21 program year to build on Australia's success in managing the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, and support Australia's continued economic recovery and drive positive social cohesion outcomes.

A well planned and managed immigration system contributes to the skills and capability of Australia's workforce; facilitates the transfer of knowledge and expertise to boost business and entrepreneurship; supports sustainable population planning; bolsters economic growth; and is key to securing social cohesion outcomes.

Well-targeted migration supports growth in productivity, raises workforce participation, and expands consumption possibilities. Migration can benefit consumers and businesses in our cities by addressing skills shortages and increasing competition in the labour market. For our regions, migration can be an opportunity to create new businesses and jobs, boost innovation, and drive greater economies of scale.

The Australian Government, however, acknowledges the pressures that increased population can put on infrastructure and is committed to maximising the economic and social outcomes of immigration, particularly skilled migration, while also considering the long-term population impacts on state and territory planning and infrastructure.

To this end, in 2019, the Government made a series of changes to address the issue of sustainable population growth across Australia, including the establishment of the Centre for Population within the Department of Treasury, in recognition of the need for a single point of analysis to assess, monitor and project changes to Australia's population. These initiatives are further supported by the publication of Australia's first Population Statement in December 2020, which can be accessed on the Centre for Population's website at: https://population.gov.au/publications/publications-population-statement.html.
Thank you for bringing Petition PN0494 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 12 May 2021 regarding petition number PN0504 requesting changes to certain Statements of Principles (SOPs) developed by the Repatriation Medical Authority (RMA).

Under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA) and the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 (MRCA), the question of whether or not a medical condition can be found to have been caused by military service is determined on the basis of SOPs. These are created by an independent statutory authority, the RMA, on the basis of sound medical­scientific evidence. Where SOPs have been determined by the RMA in respect of a relevant condition, at least one factor in the SOP must be met and related to service in order for a claim for the condition to be accepted.

The Government cannot direct the RMA to include specific factors in the SOPs and it would be inappropriate to do so, given the independence of the RMA and the role of the SOP system which is to ensure that SOP factors are based on, and claims are assessed according to, sound medical-scientific evidence on the causation of conditions. For your information, there are currently 15 conditions for which SOPs exist that include factors relating to exposure to dioxin-contaminated herbicides.

The established and legislated process for seeking an amendment to the SOPs is to request the RMA to conduct an investigation into the condition. Veterans are able to directly approach the RMA to request an investigation into the conditions that are the subject of this petition. The RMA is required under the legislation to consider such a request and provide reasons for their decisions. A request for an investigation or review of existing SOPs can be lodged online on the RMA's website at: www.rma.gov.au.

Should an investigation establish, on the sound medical-scientific evidence, that particular exposures are causal factors in the development of a medical condition, then the factor will be included in the relevant SOP for the condition by the RMA.

Thank you for taking the time to bring this matter to my attention. I would encourage the petitioners to avail themselves of this review process so that the RMA is able to consider the substance of and evidence relating to the conditions which are the subject of petition number PN0504.
The RMA can be contacted by email at info@rma.gov.au, by telephone on (07) 3815 9404 or VIA online feedback form at: www.rma.gov.au/contact us.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Chester
Foreign Investment
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for the Standing Committee on Petitions' correspondence concerning Petition EN111 - to halt foreign ownership of land.

Foreign investment drives economic growth, creates skilled jobs, improves access to overseas markets and enhances productivity. Without foreign investment, production, employment and income would all be lower.

At the same time, the Australian Government recognises community concerns about foreign ownership of certain Australian assets, including land. The foreign investment review :framework allows the Government to consider these concerns when assessing Australia's national interest while ensuring Australia remains an attractive place to invest. If it is determined that a proposal is contrary to the national interest, it will not be approved or conditions will be applied to safeguard the national interest.

In relation to residential land, the Government's policy is to channel foreign investment into new dwellings as this increases the total dwelling stock in which Australians can live as well as creating additional jobs in the construction industry and supporting economic growth. Non-resident foreign persons are generally prohibited from purchasing established dwellings in Australia.

In relation to agricultural land, the Government has acted to improve scrutiny and transparency around foreign ownership of agricultural land and agribusinesses. The Government has also clarified that foreign investors can only acquire agricultural land where there has been an open and transparent sale process, thereby ensuring Australians have an opportunity to participate in the sale process.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Prime Minister
Dear Chair

I refer to your emails of 8 April 2020 and 15 September 2020 to the former Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon Christian Porter MP, regarding petition number EN1222. This petition requests that the House put forward a motion of no confidence in the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP.
I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this petition to the attention of the former Attorney-General.
The Government will not be moving a motion of no confidence in the Prime Minister.
Thank you for raising this matter with the former Attorney-General.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Commonwealth Bank
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2111 with a total of eight signatures - inquiry into ASIC's alleged blatant contempt for the law. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) is an independent statutory authority responsible for the administration of the Corporations Act 2001 and related legislation. Under its governing statute, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 2001, I am specifically precluded from giving the Australian Securities Investment Commission a direction about its policies or priorities in relation to a specific case. One of the reasons that the Australian Securities Investment Commission was established as an independent body was to ensure that its decisions and actions are, and are seen to be, independent of the political process.
I will refer your correspondence to ASIC for their consideration.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and the Digital Economy, Senator Hume
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 March 2021 to the former Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon Christian Porter MP, referring Petition EN2272, which calls for protecting the right of employees to refuse· an employer's direction to get vaccinated against COVID-19.

The Australian Government is committed to providing all Australians with access to free, safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines. The Government position is that vaccination, while strongly encouraged, is voluntary, and the Commonwealth will not be legislating to require vaccination in the workplace. In line with this, the existing legal framework around workplace vaccination will continue to apply.
Under this framework, a worker may be required to be vaccinated where:
a public health order requiring vaccination is in place
a worker's contract or enterprise agreement allows it
an employer makes a lawful and reasonable direction to do so.

Public health is primarily a state and territory responsibility and jurisdictions may issue public health orders requiring vaccination for workers in certain high-risk workplaces. Employers and workers must comply with public health orders, and sanctions may apply for non-compliance. States and territories have previously issued public health orders requiring influenza vaccinations for workers and other people in aged care facilities in the interests of protecting vulnerable Australians. National Cabinet has recently endorsed expert medical advice to require vaccination for workers in residential aged care and quarantine facilities as an essential part of reducing the risk of transmission and spread of COVID-19 into the community. These will be given effect through state and territory public health orders.

Absent a public health order, vaccination can be required in the workplace where it is provided for under an enterprise agreement or contract. Such arrangements are uncommon, however, and in most circumstances an employer may only direct an employee to be vaccinated where this direction is considered lawful and reasonable.

A direction by an employer will only be lawful where it does not contravene relevant laws, including anti-discrimination legislation. Discrimination laws may be relevant if a person is unable to comply with a vaccine requirement due to an underlying disability or medical condition. Employers should ensure that any requirements to vaccinate are consistent with discrimination law requirements before introducing a policy that requires employees to be vaccinated.

Whether an employer's direction will be reasonable must be assessed on a case by case basis. It will depend on the particular circumstances of a person's employment, the risks of contracting the disease, whether other control measures, such as the wearing of masks, may be an appropriate way of managing risks, and the particular circumstances in which the direction is given.

As a general rule, a worker must comply, so far as they are reasonably able, with any lawful and reasonable instruction that is given by a business to an employee that concerns their employment. Where an employee refuses to comply with a lawful and reasonable direction, an employer will need to consider options for managing the employee, which may range from allocating alternative duties at one end of the spectrum, to termination at the other end.

Workplace vaccine guidance published by Safe Work Australia and the Fair Work Ombudsman indicates that the overwhelming majority of employers should assume they cannot require their employees to be vaccinated against COVID-19.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cash
Media
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 12 May 2021 concerning Petition EN2454 , which calls for the removal of news outlets from social media platforms and to regulate content.

The Australian Government supports a diverse and sustainable media sector. It also recognises that quality news and public interest journalism play an important role in the functioning of Australian society and democracy, and is essential to informing local communities .

The Government is committed to promoting the rule of law and the rights and protections we enjoy as a democratic nation. Of these, our right to free speech and free expression is one of the most highly valued and fiercely protected. The ability of citizens to speak freely and openly is the hallmark of a robust democracy.

However, there has never been an absolute right to free speech in Australia. Free speech is balanced against other considerations, such as whether speech is harmful, threatening, offensive or defamatory. This includes disinformation and misinformation that harmfully misleads the Australian public on matters of public importance.
When it comes to issues such as health and safety, including the COVID-19 pandemic, it is critical that the Australian community seek information from legitimate and authoritative sources.

In response to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's Digital Platforms Inquiry in 2019, the Government tasked the Australian Communications and Media Authority to oversee the development and implementation of a voluntary code to address disinformation and misinformation on digital platforms.

The Digital Industry Group Inc. (DIGI) developed the Australian Code of Practice on Disinformation and Misinformation (Code) on behalf of the Australian digital industry and released the Code on 22 February 2021. The Code has been adopted by Twitter, Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Redbubble, TikTok, Adobe and Apple, with other digital platforms also encouraged to sign up. Further information on the Code is available on the DIGI website, digi.org.au/disinformation-code/.

Major digital platforms sites, including Facebook, Twitter and Instagram, have complaints mechanisms for users to raise concerns about content and accounts that spread disinformation and misinformation. If users have concerns about particular content or accounts, they can report them to the platform for review.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust the information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Media

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2473. This Petition requests amendments to the News Media and Digital Platforms Mandatory Bargaining Code (the Code) to provide free consumer access to digital news media publications that receive government assistance. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.
The News Media and Digital Platforms Mandatory Bargaining Code came into force on 2 March 2021.
The Code will ensure that news media businesses are fairly remunerated for the content they generate, thereby helping to sustain public interest journalism in Australia. The Code will do this by:

encouraging the parties to undertake commercial negotiations outside the Code. The Australian Government welcomes the deals that have been struck between digital platforms and news businesses and looks forward to more such deals being reached in the future;
enabling digital platforms to publish standard offers, which provide smaller news businesses with an efficient pathway to finalising agreements with digital platforms;
establishing a negotiation framework under the Code that provides for both parties to bargain and undertake mediation in good faith to reach binding agreements;

ensuring that an independent arbiter can determine the level of remuneration to be paid to news businesses under a fair and balanced arbitration model, should the parties be unable to reach agreement; and

setting clear and workable minimum standards for digital platforms including requiring 14 days' advance notice of major, planned algorithm changes that impact news businesses. This will not allow news businesses to influence search results.
To be bound by the Code, news businesses must register with the Australian Communications and Media Authority while digital platforms must be designated by the Government.
A review of the Code will commence within one year of it coming into force.

Importantly, Australians already have free access to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS). The Government is committed to maintaining the health and vibrancy of the ABC and the SBS. The provision of over $4 billion over the three years from 2019-20 represents a substantial investment of public funds in our national broadcasters, and will assist the ABC and SBS in the provision of television, radio and digital media services in line with their Charters.

Our investment in the ABC is an important underpinning of media diversity and represents a significant contribution to civic journalism in Australia. The ABC's funding includes $43.7 million over the three years for the ABC to continue the Enhanced News measure, which supports local news and current affairs, including regional newsrooms and specialist investigative journalists.

The SBS funding allows it to continue to fulfil its Charter, providing multilingual and multicultural broadcasting and digital media services that inform, educate and entertain all Australians, reflecting Australia's multicultural society.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar

from the Attorney-Genera; Senator Cash
Australian Broadcasting Corporation
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 24 May 2021 on behalf of the signatories of petition EN2511, concerning the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC)'s editorial standards.

I have certainly been left in no doubt that the petitioners regard the ABC's editorial output as lacking in journalistic impartiality and balance. It is very important that the broadcaster's news and current affairs coverage meets the standards which Parliament, on behalf of all Australians, requires of it.
Even though the Morrison Government provides an overall level of funding to the ABC, the broadcaster has content and editorial independence.
Parliament has guaranteed this independence so the broadcaster's decisions are free from political interference.
Under this arrangement, the manner in which the ABC presents its programming is a matter for the ABC Board and executive.

Although editorially independent, the ABC Board is required to develop a Code of Practice relating to programming matters and to lodge this code with the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA).
In addition, the broadcaster is accountable to the Parliament through annual reports, corporate plans, financial and performance audits, and appearances before Parliamentary Committees.
I continue to maintain regular contact with the ABC Board to encourage them to maintain the broadcaster's adherence to its Charter, so it can provide useful and informative services.

I encourage concerned members of the public to actively engage with the ABC. Direct contact is the best way to guarantee that the ABC is made aware of the public's concerns and is given the opportunity to respond.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher

COVID-19
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2021 enclosing Petition EN2535 concerning an exemption for parents of Australians and permanent residents.

The Australian Government has previously responded to Petition EN1860 – Inclusion of Parents as "Immediate" family members for travel exemption, Petition EN2311 - Include parents as immediate family members for travel exemption and Petition EN2543 - Travel exemption for parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents, and Petition EN2611 - Allow international travel to meet parents overseas, which outlines the Government's position on including parents as an automatic exemption category from the travel restrictions for travel to Australia, and including 'travel to visit parents' as an exemption category for those Australians seeking to depart Australia.
It must also be noted that on 2 July 2021, the National Cabinet agreed to temporarily reduce the current international passenger arrival caps to manage the pressure on quarantine facilities.
As such, it is imperative that international travel to and from Australia is limited to exceptional circumstances only, as per the current exemption categories.
The Government is committed to a multicultural Australia and acknowledges the significant social , cultural and economic contribution made by those who chose to call Australia home.

We acknowledge that this is a challenging and difficult time for Australians who are separated from their loved ones overseas. However, the travel restrictions are in place to protect the broader Australian community from the health risks posed by discretionary international travel.

The Government is committed to regularly review Australia's travel restrictions policy as national and global circumstances in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic evolve, and continues to take a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, informed by the latest health advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

In line with this commitment, on 2 July 2021, the National Cabinet also agreed to formulate a National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response which outlines Australia's pathway out of the COVID-19 pandemic.
As outlined in this plan, easing travel restrictions and opening of international borders will be a phased approach that will be triggered by expert advice.

Whilst the travel restrictions remain in effect, individuals who are not automatically exempt from the travel restrictions, either for travel to Australia or depart, but have a compelling reason to travel, can submit a travel exemption request for an assessment against the exemption categories outlined on the Department of Home Affairs' website at:
https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2535 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 May 2021 enclosing Petition EN2556 concerning easing of Australia's travel restrictions for international students to travel to Australia. Your correspondence was referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.
As you know, Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia.

Until further notice, there is a prohibition on all foreign nationals seeking to travel to Australia, unless they fall within certain exempt categories or have been granted an individual exemption by the Commissioner of the Australian Border Force, Mr Michael Outram APM, or authorised decision-makers.

The Australian Government's response to Petition EN2217 - Exempt International Students, outlines the circumstances that would generally meet the criteria for the grant of an individual exemption for international students seeking to travel to Australia while the travel restrictions are in place.

International students who believe they have a compelling reason for travel to Australia may submit a travel exemption request for an assessment by the Department of Home Affairs against these exemption categories.

It must also be noted that at the present time, there is no exception to Australia's travel restrictions policy settings as a result of an individual's vaccination status or the vaccination programs which are becoming available in several jurisdictions overseas.

The Government regularly reviews Australia's travel restrictions policy as national and global circumstances in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic evolve, and is guided by the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee in relation to easing restrictions on international travel.

Implementing any changes to the current policy settings for travel restrictions and including vaccinated international students as an exempt category will be a process informed by expert health advice.
You will no doubt be aware that Australia's Framework for National Reopening makes clear that the Government supports the return of international students when conditions allow.
Protecting the health of Australians and bringing Australians home in a COVID-safe manner remains the Government's priority.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly .
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2556 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Complementary Medicines
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 May 2021 referring a copy of petition EN2559 calling for the Schedule to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Act 1994 (the Agvet Code) to be amended to classify naturopathic medicines and therapies for animal as low-risk veterinary products.

The Agvet Code is focussed on products with a chemical or biological component and that are manufactured, intended or represented as having an effect on an animal or plant. The Agvet Code does not regulate physical therapies or devices, to the extent the device has no chemical or biologically active component.

For products with a chemical and biological component and for preventing or treating a disease or condition in an animal, the Agvet Code does not distinguish between synthetic pharmaceutical medicines and complementary animal health products (CAHPs) such as herbal, nutraceutical and homeopathic remedies.

Before agricultural and veterinary (agvet) chemical products can be legally manufactured, imported, supplied, sold or used in Australia, they must be assessed by the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA). The assessment process involves a rigorous scientific evaluation of the safety, efficacy and trade risks posed by an agvet chemical product to protect the health and safety of people, animals, the environment and trade. The data and information needed to support a product's assessment varies according to the nature of the product, the claims made by the product and the intended use.

To protect animal health and manage the risks to Australia's trade from chemical residues in animal products, it is important that all veterinary medicines (pharmaceutical or CAHPs) are held to the same standards. A product that is unsafe or ineffective may be harmful to the health and welfare of animals and result in unnecessary suffering or death. Unlike humans, animals cannot make conscious decisions on their treatment, heightening the need to have appropriate regulatory oversight for these products.

The Australian regulatory framework for agvet chemical products includes a range of registration pathways for products of low regulatory concern that involve reduced data requirements, costs, and approval time compared to conventional veterinary products.

Some pathways establish standardised risk management approaches to ensure products meet the same high standard as products subject to bespoke assessment. The standards can set specific parameters as well as prescribed conditions that the product must meet. The APVMA assessment of products under these low regulatory concern pathways focuses purely on whether the product complies with the standard. The APVMA has established standards for joint health products for dogs and horses.

Another pathway allows products conforming to a particular registration 'model' to be registered more rapidly as the APVMA is already satisfied that they comply with the statutory criteria for registration (safety, efficacy and trade criteria). A registration model is currently available for equine electrolyte products. While the APVMA may initiate a registration model, most registration models are proposed by industry groups. The APVMA assess the model, and the information supporting it, in much the same way that it assesses an application for registration.

For the reasons highlighted above, the Australian Government considers that an amendment of the Agvet Code to classify alternative naturopathic medicines and therapies for animals as low-risk veterinary products is not warranted. However, the government recognises that there are opportunities for targeted improvements in specific regulatory areas.

You may be aware that an independent panel of experts has recently completed a comprehensive review of the regulatory framework. The review examined the agvet chemicals regulatory framework's aims, structure, and operation, and made recommendations to ensure it is contemporary, fit for purpose and reduces unnecessary red tape. I am currently considering the final review report. The report will be published in due course.
Thank you again for referring this petition to me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia, Mr Littleproud
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 May 2021 concerning Petition EN2562 - the nature of the evidence used by the Repatriation Medical Authority (RMA) to determine factors for the causes of diseases or injuries in the Statements of Principles (SOPs) for them.

The SOP system was created in 1994 precisely to avoid non-experts such as tribunals making uninformed judgements about complex medical scientific evidence. The system deliberately limits acceptable claims via the factors in the SOPs to those where the totality of sound medical scientific evidence (SMSE) suggests a causal link between the factor and the condition. The claimant merely has to establish the facts of service consistent with the cause outlined in the SOP factors.
The Productivity Commission in its review of veterans' compensation, A Better Way to Support Veterans, released 27 June 2019, endorsed the SOP system as 'robust and effective' and concluded that:
'it promotes consistency, predictability and transparency and draws a clear line between accepted and non-accepted conditions, based on sound medical scientific evidence [p.349].
Having considered the system, the Commission recommended that it be extended to include claims under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation (Defence related Claims) Act 1988 (DRCA).

The petition as presented requests the Parliament to replace the requirement for the RMA to act only on SMSE with a requirement to accept expert medical evidence that would otherwise be admissible in a court of law under the Evidence Act 1995.

The SMSE for the causes of a particular medical condition is limited to information that, 'meets the applicable criteria for assessing causation currently applied in the field of epidemiology'. This means the RMA currently has regard to standard epidemiological criteria to assess causation. A good example is the criteria under the Bradford Hill formulation, which are used in assessing the relationship between an exposure and the development of a condition. They include matters such as the strength of an association, its biological plausibility and the dose-response relationship. All these criteria involve inherent qualitative judgements and always require consideration of whether any suggested relationship is the result of chance, bias or confounding.

The RMA considers these matters relying on studies in peer reviewed journals. Those studies range from systematic reviews of previous research and studies involving a cohort of subjects over a long period down to individual case reports. The RMA considers and evaluates the effect of the entirety of these studies.

The petitioners complain that the process permits the RMA too much discretion. They suggest that if the requirement for SMSE was removed and the RMA was required to act on evidence that might be acceptable under the Evidence Act 1995 (EA) in curial proceedings, it would make the RMA's processes more consistent with "natural justice".

Section 79 of the EA permits a court to accept the opinion of a person who has specialised knowledge based on the person's training, study or experience, if that opinion is wholly or substantially based on that knowledge. The adoption of that requirement would require the RMA to accept an opinion of a medical specialist given without supporting medical-scientific evidence, that a particular exposure is a cause of a relevant medical condition. Such an opinion does not meet the test for SMSE, is of less probative value in considering the causes of medical conditions than the SMSE, and the effect of the current legislation is that the RMA need not have regard to it.

The proposed change has the potential to return the system to the pre-1994 situation of duelling medical experts. The SOP system was introduced to avoid that approach by placing a focus on the current medical-scientific evidence concerning the particular medical condition under consideration.

Further, the proposed change would require the RMA before accepting an opinion to consider legal questions that are frequently raised in the courts, such as whether the expert has a relevant expertise and whether an opinion expressed is wholly or substantially based on their specialised knowledge. Currently, any person including a qualified expert, can submit an opinion with supporting SMSE and the RMA is obliged to consider it.

The existing system is transparent with the reasoning of the RMA being available to interested parties, and there is ample opportunity in the existing legislation for SOPs to be reviewed on sound grounds.

It should be noted that the RMA's reasoning in establishing the SOP factors is available to interested parties. The Reference Lists setting out the material relied on by the RMA in determining a SOP are available at www.rma.gov.au. As well, section 1961 of the VEA provides a statutory right for any veteran, member or ex-service organisation to have reasonable access to any document containing information considered by the Authority for the purposes of an investigation. This includes briefing papers prepared by the medical researchers who assist the RMA.

The SOPs are required to be regularly reviewed as they are legislative instruments under the Legislation Act 2003, and new SOPs for each condition are determined every seven to nine years lest they lapse under the sunsetting provisions. Section 196E of the VEA enables any veteran, member or ex-service organisation to request a review of a SOP and to insert a new factor or vary an existing one. If there is no SMSE supporting such a change the RMA can refuse to investigate it.

The requirement for the SOPs to be based on the SMSE is to the overall benefit of veterans and members of the Defence forces. It provides an objective system based on the best evidence related to the cause of particular diseases or injuries.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Personnel, Mr Chester

From the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Interactive Gambling Act
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 24 May 2021 concerning Petition EN2592 requesting amendments to the Interactive Gambling Act 2001 (IGA) to allow online poker providers to offer their services in Australia.

Since its inception in 2001, the IGA has made it an offence to provide or advertise prohibited interactive gambling services to customers in Australia. Prohibited services include online casino-style games of chance or mixed skill and chance, such as online poker, which are played for money or anything else of value. On 13 September 2017, the Interactive Gambling Amendment Act 2017 came into effect and strengthened the enforcement of the IGA.

The potential benefits and risks of legalising online poker need to be considered before any changes are made to the IGA. Legalising online poker would enable Australians to play with operators licensed and regulated in Australia, instead of playing with offshore operators which may provide limited harm minimisation and consumer protections. Other potential benefits include business opportunities for domestic licensees, employment growth, and revenue opportunities through licensing and taxation.

There are legitimate concerns, however, that legalising the provision of online poker services may expand the overall participation of gambling in Australia. In 2018-19, total gambling expenditure reached $25 billion in Australia. This is equal to $1,276 in losses per Australian adult, which is the highest per capita in the world. Proper harm minimisation tools need to be in place in order to limit any increase in problem and at­ risk gambling with the introduction of a new gambling service.

The Government is well advanced in establishing the National Consumer Protection Framework for online wagering (National Framework). The National Framework consists of 10 consumer protection measures, including new requirements for operators to offer pre-commitment facilities to customers to limit gambling spend. The objective of the National Framework is to minimise the risk of gambling harm to Australian consumers.

Six of the 10 measures have been implemented. The remaining elements will be rolled out over the next 12 months, subject to further trialling and testing of some measures.
